Great video, but i have one "correction": i wouldn't say that Bill and Ted's time travelling is all that similar to the one from Back to the Future. See, while they do travel back and forth and jump around and do all kinds of crazy stuff in bill and ted, there's on big difference from Back to the Future: they jump around on the same timeline. For example, at the start of their adventure, bill and ted meet their future-selves, and future Ted reminds his past-self to wind up his wristwatch. Of course he forgets it, so they're short on time towards the end of the movie because they reliy on ted's watch which doesn't show the correct time. To try and prevent this from happening, when they meet their past-selves, ted reminds his past-self to wind up his wristwatch, not realizing that they've recreated the exact same situation they've already been on, just from the other perspective.
Similarly, in the beginning Bill's father searches for a key, falsely accusing Bill of being the one who took it. Towards the end of the movie, they need this exact same key, so they travel back to before the movie started, when the key wasn't missing yet, take it, place it under a bush near where their present-selves are standing, travel back to their actual time to find the key under that bush, realizing that it was in fact Bill who took his father's key, he just didn't know it yet.
To conclude, Bill and Ted's time travelling is actually more like the one from Harry Potter, the difference being they don't just travel backwards but also forwards.

In my opinion,  the definitions of time, past, present and future need to be established. Time is the collection of all events (a literal set of events) and time moves by the changing of events. An event is defined by the position or organisation of everything within the universe, so if you had the past, where you don't exist, call that event A. You travel back there, YOU ARE NOT TRAVELLING BACK IN TIME BECAUSE YOU ARE NOT IN EVENT A, you are now another event (B) because in this timeframe, you exists in the universe, which means these two events are not identical therefore not the same event therefore you have not travelled to event A and therefore you have not gone back in time. Now currently event B's matter count = event A + you, which is impossible as event A's matter count must = event B's matter count because matter cannot be created or destoryed. Lets say we ignore that, I kinda agree in one of your ideas about the two timelines being entagled, in my opinon, they are not two timelines, it is one timeline, the "timeline" where you kill your grandfather is just the future to the present from which you "travelled back in time" from. Because any event that hasn't already occured is the future, but we commonly make the mistake of percieving it as the past because one, its similar to the past in ways humans can registered information, two, its hard to see its the future because its impossible to be the future (as in, physically you cannot created event B in any circumstances). No offense but i think your proposed solution is invalid. The logic of the paradox does not allow for what you proposed. If you DID go back in time and killed your grandfather, there is no long contrived excuse that would prevent you from immediately vanishing upon his death. Your method relies on a lot of what ifs and assumptions and just clouds over the original premise of the paradox, whilst none can deny the paradox. Example. If your grandfather bought you a car 20 years ago, but you went back in time and blew up the car back then, the car would not exist in the current anymore, nor in that past. Just because we replace car with the grandfather himself, does not alleviate this logical fact. Likewise, if you went back in time to your birth and killed youself once you were delivered, you would NOT continue to exist. The more fluff you remove from the raw equation, the less conjecture interferes with the logic.

i dont think that he is right. First, blow off that nonsense about another reality by which in one the grandfather is alive and the other he is dead and thus an alternate path...blah, blah, blah. This is nonsense. As for superposition with regard to composite entities, it doesn’t exist. Schroedinger’s thought experiment was formulated to make fun of this idea. Though the Copenhagen school embraced it, even Bohr rejected it. As an example…consider the schroedinger experiment with the cat in the box. Keep the emitter and the radioactive material, the collector, the hammer, but instead of poison in a vile, use acid. This too is poisonous and would kill the cat. Now, and this would not change the experiment, have the vile of acid on a mechanism that when the cat lay down, it would tip over and spill its contents on the floor of the box. So, the collector counts the right number of particles, breaks the vile of acid, the fumes kill the cat, it falls to the floor of the box onto the mechanism, tips the vile of acid which then eats through the bottom of the box. We as observes never have to open the box to see the cat. Instead, we see the acid dripping out and know that a string of objective, deterministic events took place and that the cat is dead and only dead which is why the acid is dripping from the hole it burned in the box. Where is the wave form and its supposedly necessary collapse then? Where is this need for alternative universes and all that nonsense?

So, there is no alternative time line scenario. If you go back in time and kill your grandfather so you are not born then you cannot go back and kill him so you are born then you go back in time and kill him...etc., I believe this loop would be repeated infinitely which is what makes it impossible. Infinity is impossible in material reality. To illustrate, consider the claims by physicists that the universe is infinite in scope yet who also claim that it expanded from a quantifiable size, i.e., 10 -15 meters to the size of a grapefruit, also quantifiable during inflation and then from there on but slower. What is expansion? It is the progressive increase in number, value or measure by quantifiable increments. So what would that last increase in measure be just before the very next one was infinity? I included this to show clearly that infinity is impossible in material reality, so…this precludes this time loop which (I do believe) would have to be infinite, which it cannot be.
I think that what would have to happen is that the boy who goes back in time would certainly continue to exist until the very moment he kills his grandfather. Until that moment, there would be no paradox possible. Not sure what would happen then.

Okay.

So what happens to you after you kill your grandfather?

At first you exist in a superposition of states - in one, you exist but your grandfather doesn't, because you've shot him. In the other, he exists but you don't because you haven't been born yet.

But then you reach the point in time where you get into the time machine to go back and commit the grandparricide. After that time there is still a superposition of states; one where you exist as a very old man who once did a murder, the other where you don't exist because you vanished into the past and never came back. This superposition has nothing to do with any time loops. It exists entirely of its own accord, forever. If there weren't any such things as multiple universes before, there are now!

Essentially, you've just turned the Grandfather Paradox into the Wigner's Friend Paradox.

The problem with the grandfather paradox is that the premise itself contains the contradiction. Asking "what if I go back in time and kill my grandfather," may as well be asking: "If I do the impossible, how did I manage to do the impossible?" Logically, it's begging the question.
If going back in time and killing my grandfather creates an alternate timeline, (which, it has to, because in my timeline, I didn't kill my grandfather), definitionally, I haven't killed my grandfather, I killed some other timelines version of my grandfather. The history of my grandfather in my timeline is unchanged.

The real question should be, if I go back in time and kill my grandfather, and my grandmother decides to take revenge by killing me, can she build an alternate timeline hopping machine to pop over to "my" timeline? Probably developing some alternate version of the very technology I invented to kill my grandfather (so, in my timeline, I invented backwards-time travel, and in the alternate timeline, my grandmother invents side-time travel poetic, non?).
I'm being a little silly here, but if we're entertaining what-ifs, I can make time for entertaining sci-fi premises based on thought experiments. :)

What if by going back in time and altering an event in your timeline, it succeeds but as a result, the alternate reality also is altered so that it becomes the reality you changed. Or you just turned your reality into a identical reality to the alternate reality where the event you tried to change never happened. Or, you simply went to reality a where the event you supposedly “altered” was meant to happen in the way you altered it.
Or you went to an alternate reality that had you not gone there, it would’ve turned out exactly like the reality you came from but not all the events from the reality you came from have happened yet in that reality so you are able to “alter” them. The last one isn’t really time travel, it’s just going to an alternate reality where you know what would happen next because in your timeline it happened so you are able to take steps to avoid the event that was going to happen.

Ok, here’s the thing. Imagine that you are using a watch, while you get into the time machine (a black whole, for instance), and you are directed to the past. Your watch is certainly going to keep marking time and will show you that a few hours/mins/seconds have passed. So, you’ll be in your future. But your future will bring you to the past. Now, this is no ordinary past, it’s one where you’re able to identify your grandfather and kill him. In other words, you go to your past, while keeping your consciousness (which can precisely recognize that the error that appears in your watch’s calendar is no artifact, but the reflex of the fact that it was set in another time zone).
In your future, entropy has increased. Yet, you went back in time, where entropy is lower. So, you’re violating the 2nd law of thermodynamics. That’s actually not a problem, as the law is not ontological, but probabilistic in its nature.
However, in this future that is your past you need a higher level of information, as you need the information that was there in the first place and the information of your consciousness, which allows the identification of your grandfather (and the understanding of the discrepancy between what appears in your calendar and what you’re peers in the past assume to be correct).
Where does that the surplus of information comes from in the first place? How can you do...(whatever it is) and add information to a state of the world, without adding anything to it? Impossible to say.
That’s why I (and others) would argue that you’re not going back as yourself (with your beliefs/consciousness), which is pretty much as saying that the so called boring hypothesis is not so boring after all. In sum, one thing is to violate the 2nd law (a phenomenon that, in practice, pretty much everyone doubts that will ever happen, out of mental experiments), another is increase the information of a system out of the blue.

This is a good video, although it could be slower (as it is directed to lay people). The speed of thought and the absence of redundancy is what makes it look complex at first sight. One thing: for multiverse to apply (which is just a theory, not a fact) we would need a superposition of the two states, which is not granted by time travel, which could be achieved (theoretically) do to the nature of space/time. So, I’m not saying that the premises of the video are wrong, it’s just that we’re still waiting for a theory that can actually integrate general relativity to quantum fields.

It all depends on what logic of time travel you follow. There are 3 main theories. The first, as mentioned in the video, is that there are alternate timelines in which certain major events in your life happened differently, so going back in time and changing something wouldn’t affect your timeline, but instead it would make a new timeline in which such an event had occurred. An example of this logic being used would be avengers endgame. This means if you go back in time and kill your grandfather, you’ll just be opening up an alternate timeline in which you were never born. However, this timeline would not affect yours at all. The second theory is that it’s a closed loop. This means that while the events do happen in your own timeline, they don’t affect them, since they’re predestined to happen the same way and nothing will change that. This event has occurred many times before and will continue to happen many times over since it’s a loop. An example of this logic being used would be the movie tenet. This would mean that if you went back in time, you might’ve tried to kill your grandfather, but somebody would’ve stopped you, this is because you’re obviously alive up to the point where you’ve went back in time, which means your grandfather hasn’t been killed. This means you’re destined to fail at killing your grandfather, and this event has probably occurred a million times before and will continue to occur a million times more. The final theory is the one most people follow, which is what makes it a paradox. This is the one in which changes to the past will directly have an affect on your timeline. This means that by killing your grandfather you would in fact cease to exist, but in doing so, your grandfather would still be alive. This remains unanswered within the context of this theory.

I understand the solution but I disagree, you would observe the solution and collapse the superposition and it's unclear what a collapsed state here means. You would likely disintegrate the moment before killing your grandfather due to the effects of time travel and loops like this, which means time travel is impossible (since it instantly kills you upon arrival).

Instead, I propose an alternative. It is impossible to kill your biological grandfather in the past, simply because it didn't happen. We have observed that your grandfather survived, therefor he can't be killed until your parent was born. In the same way you can't swim upstream if the current is too strong. There's no superposition where you swim up the stream or don't swim up the stream, you simply fail to swim up.

If you observe light and it is a particle, it will behave like a particle until it is brought in superposition again. Similarly, your grandfather will behave like he's alive until your parent is born. Until that point, you physically cannot kill him.

Because of this, you could theoretically go to this separate version of the timeline you exist in and change events there. This would then allow you to in essence "kill your grandfather" without affecting your timeline. He's still technically your grandfather as your genes align normally showing family lineage.

Another theory I have is that every action causes a splintering of 'time pathways'. Every action causes a split in which an infinite amount of universes with separate outcomes exist, with infinite times where these splits could occur along our perception of time. This causes an infinite amount of infinite outcomes and ensures we can find one timezones that is suitable enough to travel to and change. This would create new splinters along that timeline, thus leaving the paradox of killing your grandpa. Then go back to my theory above and you have a feasible theory for how time travel could work. You wouldn't truly be able to change your age, but you could influence the 'you' in another timeline.
This proves to me that Neil wasn't inverted just in disguise so he wouldn't get recognized by the young version of his old friend. He can't know otherwise he'd be creating a paradox.

I think the solution is more like how a linear electric circuit behaves when it has a feedback loop: the entire circuits super duper quickly reaches a state of equilibrium where the "input" value in the "past" right before the loop, and the output" value in the future right after the loop, are already all in equilibrium.

Basically, right before you went into the past to kill off your grandfather., your past history ALREADY took into account the effects of your presence in the past. So you know, right before going into the past, that you already failed somehow.

Basically, your actions already from a universe with very filtered possibilities.

Imagine if we have Bob, and his grandfather, Bobba, is constantly attacked by this evil mister Joe, who has not only superior "future tech" technology, but also might have some or even a lot of very precise knowledge on what Bobba will do and where he will be. Let's play out alll the possibilities. In some, Joe succeeds to get rid of Bobba on the first try. In others, he'll fail again and again. Let's say Joe has a 99% chance of killing Bobba on each try and can try up to 1000 times. In how many parallel universes does Bob get to eventually be born? Not many, it is super duper unlikely.

Now we ADD the condition that Joe = Bob. Meaning: Bob must come from one of those freakishly rare universes where joe faailed at all his attempts, no matter how unlikely ridiculous that seems, from the point of view of Joe it is like if the universe is against him and his odds of killing Bobba aren't 99% per try but 0% instead, no matter WHAT he tries.

Now get rid of all the other "possibilities" of universes. We only need one, no matter how unlikely it is, it can be only one where there is no paradox. So yeah Bob goes back, fails every try as "Joe" BECAUSE from "'outside timeÉ", all events already played out: the effect of the feedback loop is already "fully taken in", so Bobba survives and gives birth to Bob, because Joe came from a future where Bobba survived to give birth to him.

The paradox comes from ignoring that the future is not a "free" future, but a self-selected future that is self-consistent with it's own past.

Either there is no time travel, or free will is an illusion.

My mind through the whole video: Why would I want to kill my grandfather?

So the question is, what does the future look like? Assuming the period between your arrival in the past and your departure from the future is in this constant double superstate, in which your grandfather both is and isn’t alive, then what happens going forward from the point in the present from which you left to go to the past? Are there two parallel futures that coexist simultaneously—one in which you exist and one in which you don’t? Because the trouble is, it isn’t that these two universe’s exist at the same time, right? The existence of one universe both causes and NULLIFIES the other. So in my mind, it’s more of an infinitely rapid vibration between two realities. Perhaps functionally there is no difference. But I think it’s an important distinction.

So that being said, if it keeps rapidly flip-flopping between realities, does the existence of each entire TIMELINE going forward do the same? Is the question of which universe is “real” actually determined by which one exists on some sort of higher dimension? That way, each timeline would be lived through the entire way from the perspective of a three-dimensional creature living within it, but if you were a creature capable of perceiving these higher dimensions, you would see the timeline flickering back and forth between each possibility?

This is all very confusing. At this point I’m not even sure if what I’m saying is coherent.

EDIT: Or perhaps the two futures are the same. Perhaps the act of traveling back and causing a paradox itself prevents you from returning. Let’s say you go back and kill your grandfather, and create this strange superstate reality in which your grandfather both dies and does not die. Because your grandfather dies, you are never born, so you disappear. But then because you disappear, your grandfather never dies, the universe corrects for this, and everything goes back to normal. The timeline plays through with your grandfather alive, you are eventually born, and you decide to go back and kill him. You vanish from the present into the past and then... time continues. By traveling back, you’ve essentially just erased yourself, with no other consequences. And going forward, you’ve basically just vanished into thin air never to be seen again.

Or perhaps time works like in the Terminator. Perhaps it does still self-correct, but not so drastically as to erase you from existence. Let me explain.

Depending on how you interpret the film, in The Terminator (the original, that is), Kyle Reese may not be HIS John’s father. That is to say, when John Connor sends Kyle back to the past to protect his mother, to this version of John Connor, yet unaffected by time travel, his father is some other man who died. And Kyle Reese is a random other guy with no connection to him. But then Kyle goes back and the very act of time traveling back and replacing John’s original father MAKES him John’s father. And I doubt Sarah would’ve ever met the man who became John’s father if Skynet had never sent the Terminator back, so the fact that it HAS been sent and has caused a change in causality means she never WILL meet this guy. The universe corrects for this the easiest way it can: using Kyle as a replacement for whoever John’s father would have been. And they explain it all by saying that the future is flexible and not yet set in stone. In other words, the events of the past take precedent over those of the future. If something is changed in the past, the future HAS to change slightly to compensate, but paradoxes can be avoided and general timelines can be maintained.

So now let’s apply this to the grandfather paradox. I go back and kill my grandfather. This breaks causality, which is obviously paradoxical. But rather than spazzing out, the universe fixes this. Perhaps my grandmother goes on to marry a new man who becomes my grandfather, or has a one-night-stand that could actually have happened in my ORIGINAL, unaltered past.

There’s another movie that I think fits this type of time travel: Back to the Future. Think about it. Marty accidentally prevents his parents from meeting and begins to disappear. This is a HUGE change to the timeline that the universe can’t outright repair by making changes. So Marty has to fix it himself, but in the process, his parents are changed from how they originally were. But wait a minute—he still shouldn’t exist, because his life differs from the timeline. But instead, the timeline just corrects for the small changes and Marty is allowed to keep existing.

I'm gonna rephrase it:

In order for the new timeline to exist, the previous one cannot be erased, since it would disrupt causality. Therefore, it exists in superposition with the new time line. It's important to see that this is not a causal loop, not the bootstrap paradox. There is no information going back in the second iteration, the paradox emerges from causality negating itself.

Discarding the "alternate timeline" solution is basically not addressing the elephant in the room, which is "WHAT will the time traveler (the sole observer) experience?"

Well, I don't think this has ever been the real paradox part of the paradox. From the perspective of the time traveler or the flow of time, everything is fine as it always works with this "parallel" causally consistent loops. If it were not killing your grandfather, just making a visit will always do little changes to your past, even if "you" is just a single subatomic particle. So, it will always end up in a next loop just a very little bit different to the current one, and a next one, and a next. There don't have to be just two of them... But from the perspective of everyone else, and yourself, "after" the loop, it is different. If it would be entangled histories happening, the moment after the time travel should or could be the moment, one of the histories becomes real. Will it be the one your grandfather was killed by someone coming into existence from nothing, or will it be the one you went back into time to kill your grandfather, but nothing happened? What will the universe be? None of these timelines are consistent. This still is the paradox. The question is, will every loop cascade end in a paradox by finally preventing the time traveling entity, be it a person or just a subatomic particle, from traveling back in time. Or will it be possible to have a loop after all the changes from the previous loop in a way that everything would end up in a causally consistent way? How would this look like? Well, it would look like everything you do when traveling back into the past already happened in the past. You can't change the past, because it already happened, even with you being part of it. This would the only way to solve the paradox, except form rendering time travel impossible.

Time travel breaks causality by definition, so there is no paradox after all.

The act of going back in time removes you from the position you were on the timeline and puts you on a different position, and whatever happens to your young self (or ancestors) in the past will not affect the you that traveled anymore, because the causality was lost.

People tend to think that the time traveling event is somehow recorded in time itself, as if it creates a permanent link of causality between the future and the past. It does not make sense. When you go to the past, you become part of it, and all connection to your former timeline position is lost.

I don't agree with the consideration of quantum entanglement at the macroscopic scale.
The superposition principle applies only to quantum particles like the quarks and leptons. Of course, the quantum states of the bosons are a little different.
Now all macroscopic objects are mostly made of the up and down quarks, electrons and gluons. As we talk about the probability states of any particle being 2, we have to account for the factor that we are composed of a combination of states of these particles. Travelling in time has to preserve the states of all these particles in the exact same manner. Even one particle having a different state is not you. And thus, a super position of a grain of sand is not two states but 10^21 (no. Of particle x 2), and rearrangement of this grain of sand into one definite state is 10^-21, which is too small a probability to even consider applying entanglement to a macroscopic particle.

There is another solution.
Time travel not only creates a new future where the time traveller does not exist, but also a new past where the time traveller NEVER existed.

Let's suppose you create a spaceship that travels faster than light.
According to Einstein's relativity, velocity affects the time flow.
The faster you move, the slower time flows.
When you reach the speed of light, time stops completely.
When you travel faster than light, time flows backwards.
Inside the ship all laws of physics are reversed. Instead of getting older, you get younger.
Instead of things falling down, things go up. Instead of walking forward, you walk backwards.
Everything happens like a movie being rewinded.
When the ship finally returns to Earth, a much younger astronaut emerges, with no recollection of having ever entered the ship.

Now let's suppose you are able to do the opposite.
Let's suppose you are able to make time flows backwards OUTSIDE the ship, instead of inside.
OUTSIDE the ship all laws of physics are reversed. Instead of people getting older, they get younger.
Instead of things falling down, things go up. Instead of walking forward, people walk backwards.
Everything happens like a movie being rewinded.

But the time traveller is inside the ship, not outside.
Inside the ship time still flows forwards at a speed of one second per second.
For the rest of universe, outside the ship, time flows backward, with people walking backwards.
Outside the ship there is no time traveller to walk backwards.
The rest of the universe which is flowing backwards in time CREATES A NEW TIMELINE, A NEW PAST WHERE THE TIME TRAVELLER NEVER EXISTED!

When the ship finally arrives back on Earth, the traveller discovers a new past, one in which he never existed. He is still able to find his parents, but they never gave birth to him.
He is able to find his children and grandchildren, but they all have a different father and grandfather.
He is still able to find his facebook page, with photos of himself, but they were created by a different person, with all the pictures digitally altered.

The only thing in common between this new timeline and the old timeline is moment the time traveller departed.
That moment is the initial condition of the system. By applying the laws of physics, you can determine the final condition of the system some time in the future.
But by applying the same laws of physics IN REVERSE, you can find a PREVIOUS conditon of the system IN THE PAST.

I believe that “time” is not a physical property or thing, but rather a human construct describing a snapshot (for a specific point in time) or progression (for the “flow” of time) of the changing states of the quantum fields. Unless you can reset everything back to what it was (at least for your local region of spacetime, I guess, might be enough for a partial time rewind?) then you can’t go back in time. So theorizing about backwards time travel is like theorizing over fiction: fun and interesting, but ultimately not useful. Its like arguing over theories about whether Homer Simpson is smart or dumb, or whatever. Perhaps fun, but meaningless.

Superposition doesn't answer the paradox: how can a couple of persons exist and don't exist in the same reality?


Superposition says that a electron CAN be in multiple spots at the same time, but not that they ARE. This means, superposition doesn't say a single electron DOES occupy a same position, it says that a electron's position is so imprecise that it CAN occupy, but not exactly it does.


By this, the grandfather and the grandchild CAN exist and don't exist/live at same time, but actually they don't, in the same PHYSICAL REALITY. Because that is purely illogical, as I said before in other words.


So, we are back in the question: how do the grandfather and the grandchild exist and are both alive, when in the same time, they are not, phisically speaking?

The double slit experiment is like that because it's happening at a scale too small to predict where each photon will be at any given time, so quantum superposition is applied in order to be most accurate without knowing its exact position for sure
Because as a whole, it behaves like a wave, but each individual photon behaves as a particle

So it's not literally saying this is in two places at once, just that it might as well be considered that way due to uncertainty

A time traveler, by definition, travels outside the normal flow of causality. They travel outside time, it is the only way they can move to the past or future. To accomplish this, they must take a supply of time with them, in their time ship, in much the same way that an astronaut or deep sea diver must take air in tanks with them in order to not die. The time traveler, during the trip, must make choices - such as where to land, or what temporal coordinates to set - and in order to make these choices they must have a personal time line of their own within the ship in order to take action at all.

When a time traveler lands, they merge with the existing timeline of the universe, and no longer need to live off of the stored time within their ship. They can freely take action.

There cannot be a true grandfather paradox.

If a person travels back in time and kills their own grandfather, they cannot erase themselves. They can erase the causal chain that would have brought them into existence, true, but - because they are a time traveler, moving outside of normal time - they are not affected by any such change. When they return to their own original time, and step out of their machine and merge with the universal timeline, they would not fade or vanish. They would not need to be in a parallel universe at all. They simply step out into a world, the same world, where their past no longer exists. They are the only being that has knowledge of the previous worldline of the cosmos, and they are a person who now exists devoid of a provable history.

They had a history, it simply no longer exists. Their experience and life remain, because they - by definition - traveled outside of time. They become an orphan of causality, a causal orphan.

That is all that is required. There is no need for paradox at all. There is no need for additional universes. If you travel outside of normal time, then any change you make in the past cannot erase yourself.

Marty McFly, in Back To The Future would not have faded. He simply would have returned to his own time to find that no person remembered or knew him any longer. He would merely become a temporal orphan, but he would not cease to exist just because his personal time merged with the worldline of external reality.
AKA no free will

Fortunately, it was mentioned, although briefly and it took awhile, but ultimately the paradox is only a thought-experiment when traveling in reverse is impossible, and 'traveling' into the future can only happen in relativistic terms - meaning, time can be slowed so much for one observer relative to another that the former is experiencing a fraction of the time duration that the latter is, but still, 'directionally' time marches 'forward.' In fact, the word 'time' is a distraction - it's more about 'causality.'

Still, you can't call the M Theory answer to time travel 'boring'. That's an interesting theory in time travel. You can't discount it. It's as valid as anything else seriously considered. In fact, your solution is still just M Theory, splitting history down the middle where the grandfather event occurs and where it doesn't. In fact, it's simplified M Theory, since it's more than 'You go back and you either kill your grandfather or you don't, thus creating two continuities where there were one'. EVERYTHING that occurred splinters it off. You arrive in the past. You are now a tiny marker more of mass on this world, breathing its air, and everything else your presence will unconsciously influence, including quantum states. More than that, literally every conscious action alters things in a myriad of ways. This man who did not exist here before... Did he eat or drink? Did he sleep? Did he rent a room? Did he need to use the restroom? What happened as a result of his acting on these things, as opposed to a situation where anyone else or even NOBODY did? What if he was hit by a car and died? What if his grandfather found out and told the tale of a man that seemed like part of the family dying in the streets before his very eyes? I don’t believe in time travel that much because if in the future or another possible future time travel existed, then surely someone has traveled to our present. Seriously, if there were to be an infinite amount of futures or “branches” then at least one out of the infinite amount of possibility’s, someone has gone to our present and messed up or told someone about it or been caught. Because the “time travelers” that we have “caught on camera” or have had “sightings”, about haven’t been proven, then time travel will never happen. Unless there are ultimate universes where the laws of physics were different, then maybe it would be possible. If time travel were real, then Harry Potter’s view on it would have to be real.
Let’s say you had the idea of robbing a bank but you also had the idea of stopping it if something went wrong via time travel. As soon as you are about to reach the bank, you from the future would stop you. Done. Because in the future, you failed and ran away. You then time traveled back to stop yourself from doing it and now whatever the consequences were that happened after you failed would disappear and act like nothing happened. So in your eyes you had the idea of robbing a bank, and if something went wrong you would time travel. When you get to the bank, you are stopped by your future self. The End. Technically there are multiple outcomes and ways to do this. The first possibility is what you mentioned first. You travel to the past in a parallel universe and time goes on with you and nothing happens except your grandfather is now dead in that universe.
The other option is if you go back to your own universe’s last and kill your grandfather then. Like Schrodinger’s Cat, the universe more or less splits into two simultaneous realities that interconnect with one another creating what I like to call a Passive Loop.
A Passive loop is a type of time loop where there is a loop happening, but it is very possible to escape and reality continues. Sure the loop never ends, but you would only experience the loop once and never comprehend the infinite times it does loop.
An Active Loop, however, is much more dangerous. This is the kind of loop where you DO experience each iteration and comprehend it all. The most common and well known example of this is Groundhog Day. Escaping these loops is either possible or impossible. If you can alter reality or make different decisions each time, you are technically piling up alternate realities and traveling universes every single time. There are an infinite number of these all exactly the same so there is no fear of running out or using too many. Your timeline forms a sort of spiral going away from the universe you started in. Looking st it from the right angle (in a higher dimension of course, everything would pile up on top of itself and all mesh together.
The other option for an active loop is that there is no way to alter reality. This will usually be due to not having any memories or knowledge of the loop. Time may be looping, but nobody notices.

That would be fine from your perspective but this same duality would also happen to everyone else's timelines concurrently. Meaning that just going back in time would cause an infinite amount of duality loops on top of the original established timeline. Simultaneously, the original timeline would also intersect the infinite timelines at the time the grandson left to go back. Therefore, the timeline would be linear until the point where the grandson arrived in the past, infinite timeline collision would take place (all timelines blended) until the point when the grandson left to go back into time. From that point forward only 1 timeline would exist, not infinite ones. Would look like this. ---x#######x--------. The point is that the paradox would be contained between 2 time intervals wheras going into the paradox and coming out of the paradox the original timeline would be the only one to exist. Therefore no paradox existed to began with and every destiny possible never could have been other than the one that we haven't written yet.

Well, question/addition: First of all, the following is only valid IF there do not exist parallel universes.

in physics, the parts of a casus of quantum superposition cannot change in any way to maintain the state they're in, so using that logic you are stuck with 2 timelines entangled but that cannot progress further then the events in question AND cannot change in any way between those events. This creates a problem, because it means that the state is only able to exist as long as it stays the same, essentially creating a time loop in which their state is only one possible progression, following the loop.

Here their are 2 possibilities: either the entire universe follows the loop; or the loop will exist in a pocket universe, while the other universe continues as if nothing happened. If it forms a pocket universe, it will be stable and will NOT collapse

Conclusion: You are stuck in an infinity time loop and if/when something (ANYTHING, even a single quark) isn't in the perfect state as it was in the first time the event happened, the state will collapse.

What is would mean if it collapses isn't that easy and not definitely possible to know. A possibility is that you create a parallel universe (only if their do not yet exist parallel universes). In the original one their will be a case where your grandfather died, and you were never born; While in the newly created parallel one its tricky to know because either you will continue to live but with a grandfather who is still alive but you will still have killed him. This is because your timeline will have skipped from realities. The other option is that you will exist but your grandfather will have died and so every event what happened after his dead in which he was involved (yes, including the ant he killed while walking in the woods) will never have happened. ( the paradoxical universe is of course the most fun one).

Part of the issue is that people believe that the act of time travel is part of the timeline.
When the whole point of time travel is to take you out of the timeline, to position you somewhere else.

quantummechanics and thus superposition only work in a tiny tiny tiny system...like photons, or atoms etc. Superposition resolves itself in the moment you measure it...imagine schrödingers cat...without the box....of course you could SEE and thus measure if the cat is alive or dead...no superposition here....same with timetravel....kill your grandfather in a sealed box and no one is allowed to look...granted, no measurement thus the possibility of some sort of superposition....kill him in the normal world....and there is no possibility of a superposition....the only way of „superpositioning“ would be a multiverse

The simple and definitive answer to the question of “Human Time Travel” is this; we haven’t therefore we never
will. This assertion is not based upon astrophysics or quantum physics but
rather simple deductive reasoning. Consider the following; if there were a
point in the future where time travel became possible, it would of course be
highly guarded to ensure it would not be misused (an oxymoron) by an individual
or government. Much was the objective at the advent of nuclear weapons,
however, time being the great equalizer, in just 74 years nuclear proliferation
has created the very real possibility that left to its own demise, humanity
will experience a nuclear holocaust. As with any major discovery, be it the
combustion engine, flight, PC’s, cellular phones or nuclear weapons, no matter
how astonishing it is initially, in time it becomes common and accessible.
Thus, if human time travel were ever possible, given our propensity to misuse
power, humanity from its conception through today, would be in TOTAL disarray
and PERPETUALLY in-flux. We are not, and there- in lays the proof that human
time travel will never happen. Humanity has shown that it simply is incapable
of possessing such awesome power responsibly and as such, time will forever
remain in the realm of an omniscient God.

"Time" exists only in the human mind. It has "direction" only because of the property of entropy. It is not impossible for a broken egg to return to the way it was, it is only very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very unlikely. Hence, the "arrow of time" we think we know as real, isn't "real" at all. There is no time travel at a macro level. Only at the quantum level. In every movie you've ever seen, or book you've read about time, when it "stops" then movement stops right? no movement (change) then no time right? So, we "experience" time as change.

Entropy.

And one doesn't have to resolve all sorts of paradoxes to live in this timeless world. The timeless world reveals itself each time thought stops. This timeless world is closest to being "experienced," in dreamless sleep. Where does the experience of time go during dreamless sleep? It goes wherever thought has gone. Into a kind of void. Reality as time reemerges from this "void" as you wake up and thought recommences.

Dreamless sleep is not the absence of consciousness, but the consciousness of absence. And, as relates to thought, not the cessation of experience but the experience of cessation. We don't "remember" it because there are no thoughts happening (and therefore none "stored"). There are ways of experiencing this same state, while "awake." When this occurs for you, you will know what the hell I'm talking about.

Simple solution, fate/destiny. Example: Say you have a glass of water that spills and ruins something important to you. You want to go back in time and prevent this. You go back in time and rush to prevent it, however it's your carelessness that causes it in the first place thus you have not changed anything and therefore there is no paradox. Or in the same events of the grandfather paradox, you attempt to go back in time to kill your grandfather however, you are prevented from doing so, no matter how hard you tried. This set of strange events would then appear as your grandfather being really lucky which could be a story he's never told anyone (or is that really crazy story your grandfather always told that made no sense). No matter what, you didn't kill him because you still exist. Again there is no paradox. This gives the illusion of fate, but it's just really cause and effect rather than fate. Something causes you to want to go back in time, so you do, then you cause the effect that caused you to go back in time in the first place. It's the only way time travel can exist in a real world way that would be consistent with what we know about time, the universe, and cause/effect.

A real world example (for those people who are religious) is the whole Armageddon thing in the Book of Revelation. We are given information about future events, therefore we could affect them, however, because it's prophecy it will always happen regardless. This means that somewhere along the lines, anyone who tries to prevent that future ends up contributing to that very future they wanted to prevent. This completely defuses the aspect of the paradox as no matter what, you are in fact, the very key to the events unfolding. This is the best explanation.

I 100% agree... as far as your example goes. I've actually been working on a story that uses a very similar concept. I worked it out on my own and came to the same conclusion.

However....

(Assuming we're still avoiding multiverse theory) How does one go forward in time after completing the act which would have removed their existence? That is, if I go back and kill my grandfather, then travel back to the future; how would it play out? I can't go to the dead-grandfather timeline because that line collapses when there is no "me" to go back in time. But the same happens to the first timeline when I go back to kill my grandfather. This is the real puzzle in my opinion.

I'll admit I only have a superficial understanding of quantum mechanics, but it seems neither timeline can exist without both causing and resulting from the other. So:
1. Does this become a closed loop, effectively preventing time from moving forward beyond the turnaround point?
2. Does time continue without me while I myself am locked inside the closed loop? Or
3. Perhaps there is an exit point which allows me to return to a future that reconciles the two superpositions.

Honestly, the first option seems far more likely. But the latter two are intriguing possibilities.

Hey

As a quantum physicist, I should tell you quantum superposition has nothing to do with doing things in parallel. In fact, during quantum superposition, particles are not doing anything. Quantum superposition is a statement about the indeterminacy of the states of a particle. If no information is available about a system from prior measurement, then the system is in quantum superposition, because the state of the system does not exist, meaning there is no such a thing as "the state of the system". The system only acquires a state (randomly) the moment you perform a measurement, which amounts to altering the wave function, which is why it acquires a state in the first place. As such, quantum superposition is a terribly bad explanation for time travel, and this video also just does a bad job at invoking quantum mechanics in general.

Also, the grandfather paradox does not really exist when you consider a purely scientific perspective of time. Time is not linear as you suggest it, it is not frame invariant, and it is not disconnected to time and quantum fields. As such, the concept of the paradox does not make sense: the paradox in the first place assumes the popular non-relativistic view on time, which happens to be far from accurate.

The real problem with time travel has nothing to do with paradoxes. It has to do with the fact that, for instance, an imaginary ratio of mass to energy seems to be physically impossible by virtue of how these quantities work, or that no exotic matter has ever been observed to exist.

I thought about it in terms of the uncertainty principle (that is, the properties of past events should be as uncertain as future ones, and time travel is the "measurement") but came to the same conclusion. There really is no paradox at all.
"You're hurting my brain."

Another issue with time travel to the past is that most scenarios assume that once you have travelled back, your existence within the timeline is still attached to its original timeline. It's possible, that, if time travel could happen, your thoughts and intentions would be altered to fit within a state consistent with the timeline you arrived in, therefore making you unable to alter it in any way, because you don't want to, or can't even remember being from the future.

I prefer the solution that if you were to travel back in time, everything you do would inevitably result in the exact same chain of events that led to you travelling back in time in the first place.  What you did was already part of the past, and was a necessary precursor to the present you departed from.  Star Trek DS9 had two good episodes like this, one where some Ferengi accidentally time travelled to Roswell, and one where Sisko went back in time and ended up becoming a famous civil rights leader by assuming the name of a person who died to protect him.  If one could travel to the past, your actions were necessarily already part of the past.

Assuming you can travel into the past, anything you do there happened in the past. Thus you will either be unsuccessful in killing your mark, or the man you kill will prove not to have been your genetic grandfather, or your father will have already been conceived. In any case, the man you kill will die on the exact same day as his previously mysterious death, which you would've heard of growing up, or else that will be the day he was attacked and hospitalized by a strange young man. You cannot beat time by traveling within it. To do that, you would have to travel outside of it, to a separate timeline. Such is the nature of time.

While it is theoretically possible to kill your grandfather before he conceives your father, it remains functionally impossible: there is simply no version of reality where you succeed.

Thus, you go back in time and kill your grandfather - do you disappear immediately as well?! No. Yes!? Of course not, because it is your present time.
Soul occupies the body around 21 days (three weeks) after conception. The biggest paradox is can you travel back in your past, when you are still born. The answer is - No. The natural laws would not permit that. Can you travel just a minute before your soul occupies your baby body - No. Another soul will occupy your baby body, hence it will be a different human being, although looking as you would.
People assume that we are our bodies. No, we are not! Our bodies are just like RPG game characters for our souls to experience material life and learn, learn, learn, gaining experience through logic and emotions.
To understand the concept of time trivel we first must understand the concept of material life (matter and space) and fine matter life (energy, soul). Time is just the container, the sandbox environment.

This “paradox” always pissed me off because the solution seems too obvious to me.

Killing your grandfather as a child would just end the lineage. After you killed him, assuming time traveling into the past directly influences the present(or future, whatever), he would be dead, causing the lineage to end. You wouldn’t be alive to time travel as a result of this, but your grandfather would already be dead. This isn’t a paradox. You’re just deleting history. It’s the same as writing an essay and backspacing a paragraph or two. You still would have killed him, you would just cease existing immediately after killing him, IF ANYTHING. It’s just as likely that you would find yourself living in an alternate reality forever. Not a paradox.

I think this paradox only exists because there is a misconseption of time. If you travel back through time, that doesn't  suddenly create a new you, because that doesn't make sense at all. 1 doesn't suddenly get 2 by traveling through time. Traveling through time means, you make the time flow differently for yourself while the rest of the world works normal.  So to travel back through time you would have to make the boiled egg back raw, but not just the egg, but also the rest of the world including your body. The only thing you shouldn't revert is your memory. So if you manage to do this somehow, you went back through time and there is no paradox. And that's that. So in theory traveling back through time isn't so complicated, but doing this in practise is extremely difficult. If you want to travel through time forward, you would have to go into a closed system, in which you can freeze yourself, so that every of you're action or organical process gets stopped until the time you want to travel. You didn't change, so that means time didn't continue. You might think, this isn't real time traveling. But that is time traveling. It might not be the fascinating way. But it is a way that works and one that we already use. Sleeping is one example of it. Another example is the refrigator. Since in there the food takes longer until it gets rotten, or better said it's time passes  slower than your's so yeah, it's not that fascinating, but it works.

I would just say everything you are going to do in the past, your future self already did.

Changing history is impossible. Think of Time as a long piece of paper. How most people think of time travel is that when someone goes back in time, they can draw on the paper in a spot that was empty, and change the paper forever.

how I see it is that when you look at the paper in the present, you cannot see a blank space and then go back in time and write in it. instead, one of those lines you saw was actually drawn by your future self, who went back into the past. When you go back in time to write in an empty spot, you unknowingly do the exact same thing as your future self did, thereby fulfilling what your future self already did.

To my understanding you just solved the problem without using multiple timelines by using multiple timelines.
The superposition of quantum states collapses once you observe it (Schrödinger‘s Cat). One interpretation of this is that whenever such a collapse happens all possible outcomes get created and create multiple new timelines.

Therefore using superposition of quantum states might sound more fancy than proposing a new timeline, but you are just hiding it away by avoiding the question: what happens once someone observed these quantum states?

The quantum superposition theory only exists because we are unable to predict the result of an action.
Let's say an action has 2 consequences, and we perform that action without seeing the results.
Then we can say that The outcome is a superposition of both the outcomes.
However only 1 outcome occurs in reality.
It's our inability to predict the outcomes which has led to quantum superposition theory.
Conclusion : It's not appropriate to use that in grandfather paradox.

I've always seen the Grandfather Paradox as a non-paradox, but for a slightly different, but somewhat related, reason.

In order to visit a previous time, then we'd require time to be hupostatic. Hupostasis means that all 'slices' of time are equally real and 'exist' somewhere 'out there'. The implication being that all states are equally real, and there isn't any super-real 'now' state.

Without this hupostatic notion of time, there can be no time travel, as there'd be nothing to 'go back' to.

After killing their grandfathers, the mistake they make (which gives rise to the apparent paradox) is to then ignore the necessary hupostasis and consider time as a noema. Noemic notions of time require that there is a single true state and that time is just the progression of change ... in noemic time there cannot be multiple competing states - and thus their grandfather cannot be in two states.

It's a rather silly mistake to make, considering that they have already conceded a hupostatic universe in positing the possibility of travelling to a prior state. It cannot now be abandoned.

So, the problem appears to be one of inconsistent perspectives.


If we were to kill our grandfather and retain the hupostatic view required for time travel, we'd only kill him in parallel, as each slice is already an independently real state. After all, there is already an equally real state in which all the atoms of our grandfather are scattered about the cosmos ... and another where his vital elements are yet to be formed in supernovea or not even yet condensed out of the plasma prior to nucleosynthesis... in other words, there is nothing unusual about him being alive and dead, here and there, old and young, in equally existing non-preferential frames.

Why then, given that hupostasis is required for time travel, should be consider it a paradox that we have complementary states? That truly is a noemic worry, and since noemas do not support time travel in the first place - they must be ruled out in our scenario.


So, let's correct the error and throw out noemic interpretations...

Now, whether the interactions of two parallel outcomes should be regarded as a kind of mobius strip of linear hupostatic time, or independent frames is, once again simply a matter of interpretation. Both situations are perfectly rational given that hupostasis requires us to view our history as a static four-dimensional shape... that shape having a mundane potential for loops, curls and twists, divergences, convergences... and even isolated islands (howsoever they might occur)

And NONE of that strange geometry is at all paradoxical if our history is a hupostatic four dimensional manifold.


The only paradox here is trying to 'have your cake and eat it too' ... that is, you manipulate a four dimensional hupostatic form ... whilst at the same time insisting that the effects of such manipulations must be evaluated as though time were simply a noema, the measure of change in a universe with a single valid state.


It's clear that proponents of the Grandfather Paradox really don't have all their ducks in a row, and should have spent more time understanding what time-travel would imply as regards the nature of the universe...

... instead, they just waved their arms and made time travel happen by magic, lazily, without following the consequences of such a universe ... and with absolutely no consideration of what such a universe would look like.

Why would you kill your grandfather?

Let's say you are a scientist and lose an important document while boating in the sea. 10 months later, you develop a time machine. You go back to get the documents in the past. But now, there is no use for you to have made the time machine, so you never do create it, but because the only way you create the time machine was because you lost those documents, so you get stuck in a paradox.

Another thing: Let's say it's your 30th birthday and a genie comes out and grants a wish for your birthday. You say "I wish I was never born." He is unable to grant it, because for you to wish that wish, you had to be born, but by wishing you weren't, you wouldn't have made the wish. Another paradox.

Some have proposed that the universe is in some ways intelligent, at least for the sake of solving this paradox, and would always find a way to prevent said paradox from occurring. For example:

First attempt: you forgot to load the gun and so you just fire a blank.
Second attempt: you miss.
Third attempt: the gun jams.
Fourth attempt: you shoot and kill the wrong guy.
Fifth attempt: you successfully kill your grandfather but then discover upon returning to the present that you and he aren’t actually biologically related—you were adopted, for instance, or your grandmother has remarried since your mother or father was born.
Sixth attempt: you manage to find and shoot your actual grandfather but he survives.
Seventh attempt: …the bullet fires out the back of the gun, and the universe eliminates you for being so persistent.

This “solution” doesn’t allow you to exist in a universe without your grandfather. You just exist as much as your grandfather is alive. Plus, the fact that this doesn’t account for what happens after the point in the future during which you go back in time suggests to me that this theory can’t really be applied to a hypothetical version of the universe that allows for time travel. Although not all things that look like paradoxes are true paradox, I think the Grandfather Paradox is pretty genuine. Quite frankly, I don’t know what’s so boring about the concept of an alternate timeline. Think of it as a loop in an infinite string which, in this hypothetical scenario that allows for time travel, is able to pass through itself. Let the infinite string represent time. The string curves backwards when time is run back, then moves forward again at the point in the past that was changed. This video essentially demonstrates connecting the end of the string to a point in the middle to create a circle, but the string has no ends because it is infinite. In short, I don’t mean to be rude, but this video’s conclusion doesn’t make any sense to me, even in a hypothetical universe in which time travel is possible, which it probably isn’t. But I welcome anyone to try to prove me wrong.

Can't happen, won't happen. Even if you can go back in time, the result will be self-consistent. You are the result of your past, so if you go back in time, it means you had to go back to create the situation that allowed you to go back in the first place.  You may want to change the past, but you inevitably end up closing the loop. Just like it's impossible to create a perpetuum mobile, it's impossible to create a paradox.

The grandfather paradox is not a paradox, because the conclusion that it is a paradox relies on the premise that the flow of time in the timeline is finite and thus stops. This is to say, there is only a paradox because we think that by killing our grandfather, we produce a situation in which we could not have been born to begin with to kill him. However, what we ignore is that we cannot stop there: it so happens that if his death caused the absence of our birth, then he never actually died, because we never killed him to begin with, so we are born. In order for the paradox to be resolved, all we need to say is that this cycle never stops. Then we never reach a contradiction. Thus there is no paradox. The cycle is looping forever.

If someone were to go back in time in the first place, it would singlehandedly violate the causality principle, because you (your energy and matter) would pop up at a specific time following one that didn’t have the initial conditions to have you exist in this specific time-space location. So thinking it would cause a greater causality paradox to kill your ancestor makes no sense.

Going back in time means you make yourself exist before being born, therefore killing your grandfather will prevent your parents and siblings from existing but will only prevent you from being born. In your case, not being born won’t cease your existence, because just by going back in time you were able to exist at a time prior to your birth, so nothing has changed for you.

In other words, you popped into existence without being born and will still exist after murdering your grandfather without any loop, split timeline or paradox.

I feel like if you went back in time and killed your granddad you would just continue living on in that timeline as an adult but could never hope to see yourself born, for obvious reasons. This would not involve two timelines, or a twist. Just one loop, the one with which you traveled back in time. So - just after killing your granddad you will alter the then future (you will not be born) - but in no sense will you have altered the past in killing your granddad (because it has, by time travel, become the present) and therefore killing your granddad will in no way halt your current or future existence because at the moment you kill your granddad you actually exist. The trick in this thinking is to realize there is no alternative timeline or twisting timeline only a discrete loop, a hop, a skip, a jump which is all contained in one consistent timeline - albeit a timeline which permits many loops or jumps of various times to propagate from it.

I'm mildly disappointed that the video brought up "going past" the time loop, but meant it only within the loop. I will therefore attempt the thought experiment of what the superposition of states is past the end of the time loop, to those not actually traveling backwards in time. Let's designate t0 as the time when you activate your time machine to begin your journey to the past. We'll designate tp as the time you go back to, when your grandfather is a kid, and t{f} as all times that are in the future compared to t0. The universe is in a superposition, starting at tp, of grandfather alive/dead. By t0, it is in a superposition of a lot of conditions based on your grandfather's alive/dead state, including you being born/unborn.

The interesting thing about most superpositions is that they occur below a certain threshold of energy/time, or position/momentum. This is where the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle dwells. (Classic form with which most are familiar is that you can't know precise position and precise momentum, because measuring one changes the other. The same is true of knowing precise energy in a system at a precise time.) We're dealing with a scale of energy and time where both numbers are enormous compared to the dE and dt required to generate the uncertainty that leads to most quantum superpositions, however. But when below those thresholds, you cannot be certain of the energy within a system at a particular time, so it can have, temporarily, fluctuations in its total energy.

This leads to such effects as spontaneous particle/antiparticle pair creation. In very brief moments, they spring into existence, and the net energy in the area drops below zero. But before the dt passes within which you could precisely measure their existence, they are attracted back to each other by their opposite charges, and do a matter/anti-matter annihilation which generates exactly enough energy to bring the deficit back up to zero.

What I'm getting at, here, is that quantum superstates that are not very, very carefully maintained have a tendency to collapse down to one measurable outcome over a macroscopic period of time. If you could create a superstate that existed on the scale of your grandfather dying/not dying before your father was born, such that you did/did not go back in time to murder him, this superstate would be very prone to collapse down to one state. This suggests to me that, at some t{f}, events in both superimposed timelines would arrange themselves such that the differences caused by you existing/not existing and your grandfather dying/not dying before your father was born would somehow resolve themselves.

Perhaps, in the you-don't-exist timeline, somebody else would remember this strange time traveling murderer showing up to kill your grandfather, and use a time machine to go back and prevent it. It may even lead to multiple loops, as he goes back to stop you, and you go back to try it, warning yourself of how you were thwarted last time, and you eventually create a massive superposition of timelines until one of them results in you going back, and your foe going back to stop you because what HE remembers is somebody trying AND FAILING to kill your grandfather, and he realizes he's that guy.

Technically the Grandfather Paradox is a paradox. Even if you had the solution, a paradox is not something that is unanswerable. A paradox is just something that seems contradictory but when investigated may prove to be true or vice versa.

Coming back to this, I suddenly find this paradox very similar to the Schrodinger's Cat principle. To explain, a cat is placed in a box with no light (well any type of wavelength in general aside from the wavelengths of electrons) and with the possibility of the cat dying (i.e. poisonous gas). If nobody looks into the box, the cat is neither dead nor alive, but the mere action of looking at the cat forces it to "choose" life or death. In how the cat is neither dead nor alive, in this parwdox, your grandfather is neither dead nor alive and you exist and do not exist at the same time. Which does make sense, but in a more complex way, assuming that when you travel through time, you travel though space as well and you end up in a place the same yet different from the intended destination (different timeline/parallel universes).

Schrodinger's Cat: You place a cat inside of a box that contains a mechanism that has a 50% chance of killing the cat, and close the lid. Quantum physics would determine that the cat exists in a quantum state where it is both alive and dead at the same time. It only becomes alive or dead after you open the lid to the box and physically observe the cat.

Of course, this is ridiculous. We all know that, inside the box, the cat is either alive or dead. If we open the lid and and discover that the cat is dead, it is NOT dead because we opened the box and observed it. It is dead because the mechanism killed it, which means it was dead before the box was opened.

What is time? It's a measurable change in states of particles, either externally visible as a translational movement or internally as as vibration, rotation etc. If that movement is periodic, we can base clocks on that. Now, "going back in time" means, that a certain amount of atoms, let's call that amount "you", are going all back to some previous ensemble of states. Maybe that's even possible. But how would the whole universe "set back" to some previous ensemble of states? It's shown in movies all the time, but noone was able to show how that would work in real life. The whole time travel thing is wishful thinking. Since time has and arrow (it's traveling in direction of increasing entropy), the past will never come back.

There are three spatial dimensions.

What if there's more than one temporal dimension and, well, time takes time?

Specifically, at a one rate of one second per second.

So, you go back in time, kill your grandfather but you don't immediately cease to exist in the future - the future is not completely rewritten all in one go. Because the consequences of your actions can only travel forward, like everything else, at one second per second.

Thus, if your grandfather doesn't have your father for another 10 years and your father doesn't have you for another 30 years, and then you don't travel through time until you're 27, and it took you 3 hours to locate your grandfather, then the consequences of your actions will take 77 years and 3 hours to play out.

Yeah, this is kind of like the superposition answer, but rather than happening in superposition, the two timelines are happening at different points in a second dimension of time.

Again, no paradox. Because it's only a paradox if you're saying that the two states are true simultaneously. Logic dictates that something can't be true and false at the same time.

But it stops being paradoxical if you use some device - an alternative reality, superpositioning or an extra dimension of time - to allow the two states to exist "simultaneously" in a non-contradictory fashion.

A thing can be true and false simultaneously, if it's true in one universe and false in another universe. Or it exists in a superposition of true and false, so it can be both. Or my version, just to blow your mind further, where time is not one dimensional but two dimensional, so whether it's true at x = 3 varies along the y axis of time. And, yeah, as we have three spatial dimensions, there is a temptation to extrapolate this to three temporal dimensions.

So time takes time takes time.

There is no paradox in Time Travel.

There is no paradox in Time Travel. The classic "grandfather paradox" of time-travel is not really a paradox at all. This classic paradox basically states:

If you time-travel to the time of your grand-father and kill him before he has any children, then your father could not have been born. Then you also could not have been born. So, if you were never born, how could you go back in time to kill your grand-father?

SOLUTION: There are an infinite number of time-lines - all simultaneously co-existing. (parallel but distinct tracks, or "flows", of time events) Every time you "Time Travel" in the classic sense, to the past or future, you are hopping over to a DIFFERENT time-line, not the one that you have been living in. So anything you do in THAT time-line is part of the "natural history" of THAT time-line, but there was no change whatsoever in your originating time-line. This DIFFERENT time-line may appear to be practically identical to your own past or future, but it is in fact a totally DIFFERENT time-line. Hence, no paradox.

A super position only exists until observation, at which time, something has to either be, or not be, and thinking of this paradox as a super position means that it both can and can't be until we actually ask "which is it?" at which time it must either be, or not be. The way I always understood this paradox INCLUDES that twist in time and following it as you did. The paradox is not that this would not happen, the paradox is that this would actually STOP TIME from moving forward and instead it would just live forever trapped in this loop of action and no action. However, this paradox also has a resolution: there is really no guarantee that after a few iterations of this loop the same thing will happen again. Let's say that the success of a your time travel happens to depend on quantum fluctuation and depending on which state you get when you travel you succeed or you die attempting to travel. Since there is a quantum possibility that you may get either state, you will eventually hit an iteration in which you die and therefore the time loop is broken. At this point we do not know how things in the universe are affected by quantum fluctuations, but it may well be that due to them, the universe is not deterministic and therefore multiple iterations of the same events are not guaranteed to happen in the same way. This would make it both possible to travel back in time and would make this time loops "untangle" themselves after a few iterations.
