I think the Grandfather Paradox approaches time incorrectly. Most people think of time as something which is 1-dimensional - we are traveling forward along a path of time which is independent on space. I see it as more dependent on space and the space-time continuum. See, imagine we are a function on a complex, 4-dimensional graph, which has already been drawn out, something we are following along (sort of like the linear theory, but it's different, just bear with me). There are axes for length, width, height, and time. Any given point in time (which is the dimension which the rest of the function depends on, just like y depends on x in a 2D function) on this function represents the position, behavior, and age of each and every particle in space. Now, since we are moving forward in time along this function representing the space-time continuum, which maps the behavior/position/age of every particle, traveling back in time would just be turning around on the function and moving in the opposite direction, to a place where we have already been. So essentially, every instance of time exists simultaneously, but we are only grounded on one point of time at once. For instance, take the function y=2x. If you follow that function to the point (3,6), the point (1,2) still exists, you are just not currently at that point. The difference here being, you can see the entire function y=2x on a piece of paper, but you cannot see the complex 4-dimensional function which our universe is on. So anyways, let's say I travel back in time to 1932 to kill Adolf Hitler, thus preventing him from rising to power and starting WWII. Easy, right? WRONG. Because, since I am only traveling backwards on the function on which we already preside, a function on which Hitler does rise to power and start the second World War, it is impossible for me to accomplish. You see, the time part of the function, the age of each particle, would stay the same, while the behavior and position would change, since Hitler survived before but dies now. Therefore It would be like traveling along the 2-dimensional function y=2x, and, upon reaching the point (3,6) you decide to go back to (1,2) and change the x coordinate without changing the y coordinate. It wouldn't work. It couldn't, because it would change the function without changing the function. It would create a hole in the function. So therefore, (and, again, I know this is confusing, because I have spent many hours pondering it, so try to bear with me for a few more sentences) any time travel to the past, (or the future for that matter), is already ingrained in this function of space-time, shaping history either by intention or by failure to change it. A good example of this is the Terminator movies. Why, you might ask, can't the technology through which Skynet is created be destroyed? Because the function of space-time required for Skynet to be created. If the Terminators were not sent back in time until the 2020's, how could Skynet be created before then using their technology? Because although we cannot see the function, it still exists all at once. There is truly no "going back", per se. In the 1980's, a Terminator appears out of nowhere and is destroyed. Then the tech is used and the rest is (movie) history. So in conclusion, if I WAS to travel back in time to 1932 on say, April 17, 2034, it would not magically open a new timeline on which I existed in 1932. I already existed in 1932, I just don't know it yet because I have not reached the point in time in which i travel back to 1932 yet. Interesting, isn't it? Anyways, thank you for reading this and sorry if the explanation is convoluted or unorganized or confusing. Tell me what you think of this or ask questions if you have them. I don't know if this theory on time and time travel has been proposed before, it may have been (or maybe I come from the future where we already know).

I think the reason why time travel is so confusing, is because it is a thought process based on an impossibility. It's like the unstoppable force against an immovable object. They both don't and can't exist. Time travel is based on the concept of time and the idea of being able to travel back in it. Both of those are wrong though, because time doesn't exist. Time is a method of measuring energy displacement. There is no past to go to, because we are always in a current state of the present.

In order to have the illusion of going back in time, you would have to force all energy to reverse it's path to exactly the same as it was before. Even then it wouldn't be the past, just a picture of it. In order for someone to travel back in time, he would have to be brought summoned back by something that is outside of time, that can create an echo of his consciousness at a certain point in, what we call time.

The double slit experiment shows the effects of recording devices on quantum measurements. You shoot photons at an experiment so you can read the results. Normally these photons are negligible to the experiment. The problem arises when you measure something small enough for the photon to change the result. Think of your cellphone falling inbetween the seat in your car. Your hand is the photon, the phone is what you are trying to measure, and the closer your hand gets the phone falls deeper.

At first it seems logical, but there is a mistake. Since this version assumes there is only one history, when you killed your grandfather the first time, he was killed, after that, you are not born. And since you are not born, your grandfather will not be killed. But stop here, there is an error here.

When you assume you are not born, then the next conclusion: your grandfather will not be killed, is actually wrong. Because even you are not born, you grandfather was already killed, remember, there is only one history here. There is no event that make him come back to life. So the paradox stands still.

The main issue with these theories is that we don't who and what time travel affects. Assuming you can travel back in time and kill your grandfather, who is to say that it will have an effect on your existence? While you did exist in the present timeline, by time traveling, you now exist in the past timeline. Thus what happens to you, at least, should not be effected. Think of it as this, rather than the many timelines you would technically be creating a new timeline. Not exactly the many worlds theory but close.

You kill your grandfather in your actual past (same world) but the action of time traveling creates a new timeline. And when you travel forwards, you will find a world in which no one knows who you are. You did not exist technically, but your time traveling allowed you to keep existing thus no paradox.

Timeline ---> present ---> past --> new present

If this were drawn out, time would be like a straight line and the time travels would be the branching points. The straight lines would end where you time traveled. The argument is in relativity. The time traveler is the observer and thus effectively standing outside of the changed time by jumping around. Everyone else is affected by it though...
Or alternative timelines? By killing the grandfather you cut yourself off from the original timeline and return to one where you may as well never have time travelled?

Whenever I have time to basically think, I think about a lot of stuff. A few months ago, I did think about one of these exact "paradoxes" and came up with a theoretical solution:

Assumptions:

Let's assume you are capable of time-travelling to the "past".
Let's also assume that you are coming back to your same timeline(which would mean YOU from the past in that past world is the same as YOU from the present you travelled from and therefore the same being).


Theory:

Then, my theory is that travelling to the past would not change anything(even if you wanted or were going to) because in the case you wanted, it should have already changed the present or future.
Now, in the case you actually "changed" something in the past, it would not change anything in the future you came from, for the mere fact that the future you are coming from already counted with you eventually going back to the past in order to change the future.
I may not supply any example as there is no evidence of time-travelling. I may not make up an example as it could distort the form of any person in history.

Conclusion:

As a matter of fact, my theory does not imply a time loop, but a continuous line of events which already counted with any possible variations(as all possible "variations" are already taken into account, these should not be called in such way) in each frame of present encountered in all three: past, present and future.

The correct answer is that time exists, like space, as a full fabric and not linear to events. Points are linked via causality, which can link future to past as much as past to future. Thus, a future causal event has already influenced the past occurance. The fallacy is in considering the future as somehow yet to occur rather than part of a unified past, present, and future which have all already occured. This extends to ANY paradox except for most versions of Stable Time Loops, where original event A causes time travel departure B, which causes new event C, which ALSO causes time travel departure B. Even then though, it can't be an item (or person) infinitely looping in time, or else its subjective time will cause it to disintegrate via entropy and crash the loop anyway. "Infinitely" being the key word here, there's no reason an item can't go back, coexist with its younger self, then continue existing after the younger self goes back. Ideas, of course, do not have this problem, so Sonic can go ahead and teach his younger self how to Homing Attack without causing problems.

So in this situation then do you halt the progress of time past the point at which you travel back? Realistically if we are assuming a single timeline solution in this case then the moment that you kill your grandfather you are in essence ceasing to exist and dying, but the universe is simultaneously undoing everything that you had done up until that point. The problem that would have to be addressed here is the idea that you will break some physical law in how the timeline is reset. If however, we view time as a derivative of some larger construct of continuity we could theoretically conceive of a scenario in which you can kill your grandfather and retain your physical form and experiences, but you have then essentially rewritten time and draw the similarities between the multiverse theory. The trick to this approach is determining some form of relative time that can be tracked on an individual basis.

The superposition idea falls flat. Even if we accept that you and your grandfather can actually exist in a superposition of alive/dead states, a "measurement" of either you would cause the superposition of states to collapse to a single state. Just as Schrodinger's cat is either 100% alive or 100% dead the moment you open the box, so you and your grandfather will be 100% alive or 100% dead the moment either of you produce any measurable effect on the rest of the universe, and we have the grandfather paradox once more. The re-introduction of the paradox is unavoidable because you killing your grandfather is a measurable event that would cause your superposition to collapse into the "alive" state, and your grandfather fathering your parent is a measurable event that would cause his superposition to collapse into the "alive" state. So even if it's possible for a person to exist in a superposition of alive/dead states, neither you nor your grandfather would be actually be able to under the circumstances of the paradox.

The only way to avoid the paradox with this superposition idea would be if you and your grandfather both completely vanish from time and space ... which upon further reflection might actually be a reasonable resolution to the paradox.

I designed an actual time paradox experiment that you can actually do. It's a variation of the quantum eraser experiment in which a photon is split via a crystal,  with each half being entangled with the other and having half the energy. The double slit experiment is set up so ine happens after the other, and that second one is what's observed. The act of observing the second impacts the first through time. In my variation we freeze the second photon (the speed of like is only constant in a vacuum and can be zero) and then decide what to do with the entangled half only after the results of the first come in. We'd have to set up the second experiment in advance because we can only freeze light for about a minute last I checked,  but the choice to observe can be decided quickly.  If the first photon behaves like a wave it means a message from the fuure from it's entangled half was observed, so we won't observe the second one. If it behaves like a wave, we will observe the other. We just do the opposite which ensures that a paradox emerges. Since we know the quantum eraser works, this experiment will either create a time loop, a paradox,  or break entanglement.

I don't see this a solution to the paradox. Superposition and entanglement in quantum particles is dependent on coherence in wave functions, which is destroyed in larger non-isolated particle systems. That's why macroscopic objects don't inherit quantum properties. To propose that the event that you kill your grandfather, a very macroscopic event, can exist in some kind of superposition is therefore quite preposterous, as it goes against all of quantum physics. But then again, the possibillity of time travel is already far fetched given our current knowledge of physics. Anyhow, if we don't base our proposed solution on things that are physical possible, we might as well say that the solution to the grand father paradox is that there exists a magical, timeless unicorn that kills time travellers before they manage to alter the time line

I think it would've been worth mentioning that both solutions you presented in this video are currently considered to be "duels" of each other, so to speak. The Many Worlds Interpretation and the Copenhagen Interpretation are just different "views" about the same phenomena.

You either see "every possible outcome is happening at once until you observe it, and there's only a single universe", or you see "every possible outcome is happening at once, each in its own universe, and you only can observe one of those universes (the one you live in)". Either way, the result is the same.

For what you suggest to be true, you would have to envision that at the exact instant you kill gramps you would disappear, which would cause you to reappear, kill gramps and disappear. Solution:

The grandfather you kill is not really your grandfather.

BUT SERIOUSLY

If someone travels back into the past, then their future-self has spent "some time" in a past-time location of their timeline - they're present in that time's history. Therefore, any intention to kill your grandfather failed. It necessarily failed because we know you, the timetraveller, who was begotten from your grandfather's progeny, is alive. [EDIT: OR, if you succeed, you descend from children your grandfather already had] In other words, knowledge told us what did not happen in the past. It's like how we work other things out in history.

(See a paper from Nicholas Smith called "Bananas Enough for Time Travel")

The way I see it, doing this physically couldn't change a thing, and here's why:

Let's say you exist, then go back in time and kill your grandfather, then go forward in time. Now, to do this, you have to be alive in the first place. That can't be changed by time travel without stopping the time travel in the first place, no matter what you do, you will exist. Continuing that line of thinking, it would be physically impossible to truly stop yourself from being born by killing your grandfather because doing so would stop you from existing, and because you had to come into being to do such a thing, even if you actually managed to pull it off, nothing would seem to change because of it because you have lived your entire life in the world resulting from that.

If this is hard to understand, the same idea can exist with killing or even just seeing/interacting with your past self. It's easier to understand if we start from the beginning of the timeline, so let's do that.

Let's just assume that at the age of, say, 10 you meet your future self, who is 20. Your past self returns to their own time, and everything goes normally (if a bit odd) for the next 10 years. When you are 20, for one reason or another, no matter what happens, you can go back in time and pick to visit your past self when you were 10, then go back to the present. That past self is actually the exact same self that you were 10 years ago, and now you're just on the other side of the conversation. You had seen your future self and remembered that experience, which means that you must've had it happen, and for it to have happened, you would have had to go back in time to meet them, so not doing so would make you a different person than the one person that you can possibly be, so you would have had to do so.

Even if killing your grandfather did result in you never being born, it wouldn't matter anyway. The universe wouldn't discriminate over your matter existing at the point in time where you killed your grandfather, so you'd continue to exist. The only implication would be that, if you were to return to your normal time, nobody would remember you as, indeed, the footprint you'd left would have been removed.

Think of yourself as a shoe. Your life up until the point that you traveled back in time is like a footprint left by the shoe; your birth, the memories of you that are held by others, any impact you'd have made through your existence in that time period. That footprint would be wiped away, but the universe wouldn't discriminate over the shoe that left those footprints being present in the past. A shoe, like our bodies, is just matter. The memories we have, as a result of how our brains work, aren't reliant on things actually having happened (as evidenced by false memories). Both the matter that makes up your body, and your memories, would continue to exist in the present you're experiencing.

Why have superpositions never been observed macroscopically? I mean, cats that are alive and dead at the same time, for example? Mars existing and not existing at the same time? Really, just think for a second and ask yourself why a supposed wave-function collapse is conjured up to explain the fact that superpositions have never been observed. Or that many worlds are created upon observation... Really? Where's the empirical evidence for this? Sure, some scientists have stated otherwise, but upon closer inspection of the studies that supposedly observe these states, in reality have never observed them. Such people conflate math and computer generated images with empirical observation. The guy in this video does not appeal to science (through empirical observation and experimentation) , but rather, to philosophy and math...

Besides, superpositions, as described in the video, violate the law of non-contradiction. This means that such an imaginary construct is logically absurd. Superpositions are useful mathematical tools for predicting outcomes, nothing more... It's common sense, superposition takes into account many possibilities, so an accurate prediction can be made. Science relies on logic, and not vice-versa, and thus, the law of non-contradiction cannot be shown false in any instance, and be appealed to describe some real phenomenon while having been proven false (which is logically impossible anyways)... The cat is alive, or the cat is dead, not both...

Quantum physics has created too many physicists that believe they're doing science, when they're really doing math or philosophy... The successes of quantum physics can be explained by the successful predictive models that take into account possible effects, but superpositions being treated as real, and not mathematical possibilities, is not a correct description of the causes of those effects being observed (if they refer to superpositions as actual and not possible).

In anticipation, no, our reality is not block time. We experience a past, present and a future. How else do you explain the subjective experience of time passing? It's illusory? Where is the empirical evidence for this (that means not appealing to mathematical theorems or unobservable superposed states and multi-verses)? Superposed states aren't classically logical, since they violate the law of the excluded middle. So on the vast majority of people's understanding of the word "logical", this solution is not logical. You mgiht get people familiar with any paraconsistent logics, or the dialetheists out there, to agree that the solution is logical. Maybe.

But that's OK, because superposed states don't have causal interactions. IE, while it is in principle OK to describe the two outcomes as possible realities in superposition, only one reality can actually exist, representing the collapse of the superposition.

The entire premise of the grandfather paradox is false.  Assuming time travel is possible, if you traveled back in time to kill your grandfather, you could not do it because your grandfather is alive.  If at some point in the future you travel back in time, say, to 1940, to kill your grandfather, future you has already existed in the past because 1940 has already happened.  Something in the past prevented you from killing your grandfather because you know your grandfather survived; it already happened.

If the uncertainty principle holds (as in, you cannot measure a particle's position, go back in time, then measure its energy as well) then reality only has a probability of being identical every time and therefore only has a probability of continuing the same way in each iteration of the loop.

If a time loop repeats itself, then each time there is a small chance of a different result due to the probabilistic nature of reality under the uncertainty principle.

This time loop will continue to run until every possible quantum configuration occurs OR until a configuration is reached where the event that causes the loop (killing your grandfather) does not occur - which would collapse the time loop.

Because of this, any paradoxical time loop will collapse to a failed paradoxical time loop.

Any attempt to cause one would get thwarted by some event which is likely to be a very slight quantum change that cascades into a serious result. e.g., a neuron misfires and you get a seizure, the time machine fails to work, a bird gets a seizure and dives into your eyeball, etc..

You haven't actually changed anything from your branching explanation by using superposition. All you're doing is changing perspective.

There's a video you're probably familiar with that explains how to visualize multiple dimensions. Zero dimensions is a point. Extend the point in one dimension you get a line, comprised of an infinite number of points. Extend the line in another dimension, you get a plane comprised of an infinite number of lines. Extend the plane a third dimension and you get a 3D cube, comprised of infinite 2D planes. We're all familiar with that so far.

Now, compress that 3D cube so that it's now represented by a 0D point, and extend that point into a line, and you get the 4th dimension, which is time. Look at any point along the line, and expand that point back to its actual 3D status, and you would see a moment in time - the first landing on the Moon, the signing of the Declaration of Independence, Shakespeare penning "To be or not to be", the building of the pyramids, etc.

Now, extend that 4D timeline into a 5D time-plane. When you go back to kill your grandfather, you draw a second line in that plane that represents the new timeline. Essentially you've just drawn a Y on a piece of paper. However, if you were to tip that plane on its edge, to view it from our standard 4D line vantage, you would see the two lines superimposed on one another.

Well that was a well thought out video from someone who doesn't understand quantum physics. That's typical of people who smoke weed.

Quantum theory does NOT allow for a particle to both exist and not exist. The main reasons is that non-existence is not a property or state. You can not have an electron, for example, that has non-existence as a property.

To put it another way, being in the state of alive and dead simultaneously is completely different than existing and not existing simultaneously.

Keep things grounded with correct wording and you may 'take all the fun out of it' but at least you won't be feeding foolishness.
Our collective minds are not going to suffer from some sort of creativity deficit just because we could get better and separating imagination from theories or sound hypotheses.


The cognitive dissonance here seems to occur in the process of 'defending the entertainment value' by 'suspending the disbelief' .If you said 'here we have a paradox that is based on something that's actually impossible, and there are no decent theories to support it. There aren't even sound hypotheses, but let me go on the explain this impossible thing anyway.' I guess that would take all the fun out it, right? It wouldn't keep getting said. So...it can only endure in a false form...like OTHER FALSE BELIEFS. Just be aware of what you are doing. It's like you are 'citing evidence for aliens'. Or evidence of the 'flat earth conspiracy'. It may be a little more 'innocent' but not necessarily any more plausible. but it's not without impact. In fact in it's subtlety of implausibility it's even a bit more at risk of become widespread beliefs. As in 'there (probably) ARE other parallel universes that you could go to, to get around the impossibility of reverse time travel'. That is a CLASSIC example of a mechanism of cognitive dissonance. If you can't support the impossible with anything reasonable, simply make up something unreasonable to support it. And of course grab for the least unreasonable and most fitting you can find, even if it's actually still quite unreasonable.. I'm not saying this happens with intent or malice. But it's a thing, ok? If I seem 'uptight' consider that to be less like I'm being is to be even more tolerant of collective delusions. So my urge to not seem uptight is overtaken by my sense of responsibility. Society doesn't take a lot of things as seriously it should for it's own good (and vice versa). Lying (to itself) is one of them.

ALL THAT SAID, in like form, in the end, I will say that in spite of offering apparent support for an absurd hypothesis earlier on you do seem to redeem yourself with a better framing of it near the end. And it was also an interesting reference. So for that, you get credit. But you didn't say all that first, and you didn't thread it throughout...the delusion is still promoted despite the honorable mention of caveats. Because as you know a lot of people aren't going to remember or focus on the caveats. So what to do instead?
Don't call an absurdity a paradox. There is no 'solution' to such a thing'. We can apply logic 'solutions' to such absurdities, but we are in danger of thereby 'validating them with a serious response'. Don't try to offer solutions to the alien invasion under such a pretense.
I'd say just focus on the caveats from the beginning and throughout and marginalize the delusion, discredit it, and frame it as obsolete, boring, and even its name can be obscured...'that thing we used to say'... Brilliant people should maybe not work
so deep in the weeds when no disproof is really needed in a practical sense. I guess it might not seem so absurd to them at the time, idk. That's not anything to be regretful about. Just a chance to examine one's overall epistemic underpinnings. Maybe put some more emphasis there instead of just the specific consideration at hand.

The only way for time travel to avoid paradoxes is through two methods.

First is that you are traveling to another "version" of reality, in which you are not affecting the future at all. This would allow you to do anything without it possibly affecting you or creating a paradox, but also makes the term "time travel" a bit inaccurate.

The second method is that you do go back to your own past, but in this case you will be incapable of doing things that did not actually happen in the past. If you try to go back and kill your Grandfather, you would have already tried to do that and not have been prevented from being born - so the only logical conclusion is that you failed to do so.

The first method isn't true time travel. The second method makes the idea of using time travel in order to change the past impossible.

What I find comical is in movies and media that depict time travel, however, and completely ignore these basic logical paradoxes. I may be unique in this manner, but I can't enjoy a story that involves such an obvious paradox. Something stupid such as going back in time to kill Hitler, for example, when anyone with half a brain would realize that it is impossible to do so and affect your own past. If it was possible to do so, then logically no matter when you decided to do said time travel it would have already happened in your own past - but for something like that, we already know that it did not.

What did not happen cannot happen, in other words. No ability to travel back in time could change this. You could still influence the past, but all of this would be stable and have already "happened" in the past - meaning you traveling back in time in the first place is essentially predestined.

Humans are made of particles. "Time" just tells us (approximately) where a particle is at a given "moment". If you travel back in time, the particles that comprise your body in that instant will be separated and returned to where they were before they were collected into the mass known as "you". You will live your life in reverse until you reach the point where your "travel" stops. If you try to travel to a point to before you were born, you will simply be "unborn", you will reverse-live until you are a baby, fetus, zygote. The particles comprising the cells that formed you will continue backwards in time until the time reversal stops. How slowly or quickly it happens depends on how powerful the spacetime distortion was. That takes a MASSIVE power source, by the way. Chances are your "time machine" would likely be more along the lines of a supermassive black hole or some other extremely powerful, naturally-occurring cosmic cataclysm.

A human being is the sum of its parts, and those parts are moving, vibrating points OF spacetime, not IN spacetime. We are not objects traveling THROUGH spacetime, we are MADE of spacetime, we are collective vibrating points of spacetime itself. Going back in time just means reversing the flow of energy, like pressing the rewind button on a tape recorder. But will the same song still play? Not likely.

Once "your" particles go back through spacetime, the chaotic and randomized nature of the universe means that "your" particles, now likely miles away from one another, are not destined to become "you" again. They are actually much more likely to get roped into doing something else, becoming constituents of another person or object, perhaps a clump of dust somewhere. Your entire existence hinged on a very specific universe existing in a very specific state, but that state always changes, randomly. Destiny does not exist. You were a random event, and the chances of that event repeating itself are nearly zero after one rewind. If the universe was rewound infinite times, you'd probably spring up again from the chaos, but who really knows?

The problem with this solution is that it ignores the duplication of matter.

When you go back in time the atomic nuclei of your traveling incarnation already exist in the past as parts of your earlier self or other pieces of matter (food you haven't eaten yet, water you haven't drunk yet, O2 not breathed yet, etc.).

e.g. if you went back only 3 months in time, the majority of your non-H2O atoms in your body would be the same ones. Electrons come and go but protons and neutrons last for long periods as nuclei.

How do you explain the energy required to essentially re-introduce the identical particles into the same temporal existence?

This is why I don't think that time travel into the past is possible: Atomic nuclei are already "committed" to other roles and duties.

Another resolution is that you appear in the universe c*timeYouTraveledBackInTime away from your 'path' through the universe.

If you're always at least c*timeTraveledBackwards away you don't influence your past and because of relativity of simultaneity. So it's like you effectively didn't travel back in time it was more like you appeared a large distance away and had time to do things while the information of your arrival traveled. So the effect of time travel will become apparent to the person as they travel towards your new location. Effectively you have time traveled from your own point of view because the information/light you're getting from where you were is very old and everything seems old. But once time 'catches up' you'd eventually begin to see your actions at your old location. But the actions you've taken at your new location doesn't influence those. So you can see yourself enter the time machine (given eyesight that lets you see yourself light years away) and you have no way of affecting it.

The video really doesn't even answer it's own question. What happens after the time loop, or rather, would someone outside the time loop know of the person's existence or not? There are actually several answers to this paradox. The multiple timeline theory, as this video mentions, fails because its not even time travel, but merely multiple universes offset from each other. It also raises the free will problem, because your counterpart who is one hour behind you will make the same decisions you do, and you will perfectly copy your counterpart who is one hour ahead of you.

I personally favor the Novikov self-consistency principle, which states that anything that a time traveler does in the past has already happened. For example, if one were to travel back in time, kill baby Hitler, and replace him with an orphan, that orphan will grow up to the Hitler known to history. Under this theory it is impossible to travel back in time to fix history, but is also equally as impossible to break history, because anything you while time traveling has already happened and must happen. So, time travel could be used a historian to gather information with no risks of time paradoxes, alternate histories, and the like.

Well, I am going to stick to the position that the "time travel" is impossible to begin with.  People like to think their lives play out as a movie in our universe, when it is more like food coloring dispersing in water as it reaches maximum entropy.  If you were to make this time hop, either into the very same universe you are in, or one identical to it, matter would have to be destroyed, when you leave, created when you arrive, and/or impossibly assemble from the wave functions of whatever that matter was doing that currently makes you up from where it currently was at that time.  Matter can't dual exist, be created, or destroyed.  The paradox runs a lot deeper than the proposed thought experiment.  Hopefully, I didn't dash anyone's time traveling ambitions.

And now I'm wondering about time in video games (in the few games that I've played that have featured time travel as a game mechanic that you have to play with). Usually in these games you have two distinct, specific "moments" running in parallel with each other, between which you can cross freely. You can safely travel two a specific moment again and again without creating duplicates of yourself, which could leave one to believe that the character has been detached from the laws of reality and exists as a separate entity, able to interact, but never truly be "present" (wink wink). Aside from that, these generally seem to run on the "overwriting reality" principle, where any action you take in the past moment has a permanent effect on the future moment (uuuuntil you change the past again), without any further complication.

I think the biggest problem with this whole debacle, the whole "Grandfather Paradox" discussion, is that it rests on faulty assumptions. For the paradox be considered a possibility, one must first take the position that the past and future are somehow stored somewhere, as if the universe was a colossal computer program. Moving through time in this (bizarre) perspective would be simply adding a few lines of code to a specific time period, a line of code representing "you", so that a previously absent variable could alter the flow of time.
But the fact is that previous, nor future accounts are not "stored" anywhere besides as a representations in your hippocampi. Past and future are not tangible "stuff". Time may be "stuff" in Einstenian physics, but past and future are definetly not.

I think of the Grandfather Paradox not as some perplexing puzzle, but as being like a contradiction proof. In a mathematical proof, you can say, "Assume x is true. Then y must be true. But y is false, so x is false." In the same way, the Grandfather Paradox is the contradiction that proves that time travel is impossible under the classical assumptions of causal determinism and that the universe has only one state at each instant of time. This video is less like a solution to the Grandfather Paradox and more like a changing of the assumptions so that the paradox doesn't apply anymore.

If you're of the opinion that you can "change the past" then you're thinking too linearly. Linear thinking leads us to believe that cause is followed by effect. You do something, and it effects a change later on. When discussing temporal loops one must remember that causality is no longer linear. Your effect can occur before your cause. It can even be the cause of your original cause, turning causality on its head. In simpler terms, if you have time-traveled into the past, whatever you do in the past has already occurred in the past, before you choose to travel there. Or... choose to travel then, I suppose. Your free will is not being taken away; it's not that you can't kill your grandfather, you just know you haven't because you exist.

Here is the problem I have with the grandfather paradox, it proposes that changing the past is impossible by virtue of this paradox, when all it really suggests is that it's impossible to change YOU OWN timeline/history.

If you add an additional person to the mix, all of a sudden the paradox vanishes. Because the person that went back in time to kill YOUR grandfather, their time line remains unaffected.

If fact at most, all you would have to do is some accounting, and go forward in time, and give yourself a note or explain why they need to go back and time and kill X person to maintain consistency.

Paradox resolved, Consistency accounted for and maintained.

Here is a weirder "paradox": What if you are your OWN grandfather, which was touched upon in FUTURAMA?

If you go back in time, you exist IN THAT TIME, not in the future. Therefore, if you kill your grandfather I would think that nothing would happen to you at all, since you now exist before you were born to begin with. The very fact that you have traveled back in time removes you from the chain of events that lead to your birth in the future. You wouldn't "pop" out of existence, since your existence is not connected to the future, but the present. Think of it as if you went back in time 20 minutes and killed yourself before going back in time. Before you pull the trigger there would be two of you in existence at the same time. The two "you's" are separate conglomerates of matter, made up of different atoms, so destroying the first "you" would have no effect on the atoms in the second "you". So just extrapolate this out to your grandfather and you get the same result.

The real question is this: What if you kill your grandfather and THEN go back to the future? Since you would now be in the future, where existence depends on events in the past, and your grandfather is now dead, would you pop out of existence? Or would space/time not even allow you to do so, since the matter that you are made up of would be in different forms and objects in the future? Perhaps this is the precise reason time travel in reverse isn't possible? It would require matter to be in two places (or more) at once, and even though this happens on a quantum level, it's not possible on a macro level.

The solution is there are multiple realities running in parallel to this one. Call the universe you are in now universe A. You at some time use a machine to travel back in time. The reality you appear in is NOT universe A. Call it universe B, which was exactly as universe A was up until the time you appeared. You are now free to do what you like. You have disappeared from universe A (and can only reappear in it if you go back to it to sometime AFTER you left). In universe B you can murder your grandfather, or hell, yourself as a kid if you really want to. YOU don't stop existing, cos you're from universe A.

Hope this made sense. It really is the only way to make "time travel" logically consistent. Think of it less as time travel, and more as travel between realities.

What a silly topic. You can't travel backwards in time at all. As energy in matter speeds up, time slows down and vice versa. In order for mass to exist, it requires energy as a Yin/Yang relationship. Can't have mass without energy, can't have energy without mass. In order for anything to go backwards in time, energy would have to slow down and cross "zero" into the negative side of the spectrum to begin a reverse. But if you have zero energy, then you have zero mass as well (or Infinite!) and therefore do not exist anymore. That's why even the most densest and high energy places in space (Black Holes) only slow down time CLOSE to zero, yet it cannot hit zero.

If you cannot travel back in time, this "Paradox" is not a paradox at all. It's an uneducated hypothesis at best.

It's an interesting quick step to show some advanced physics, but:

- either time is linear and you can't go back in time, ergo there is no paradox in the first place;

- time is not linear (otherwise you wouldn't have the paradox in the first place).

In neither case however (both of which are just thought experiments) it is taken into account that we only perceive time as linear, whereas time is just a function of space: the space-time continuum, or simply space-time. So instead of juggling with timelines and parallel universes, one could simply pose that 'travelling back in time creates an insolvable paradox'. Why? Simply because if you actually were travelling back in time that simply implies a temporal regression. Simply put: if you are 50 now, you'd be successively, 40, 30, etc, an egg, a cell, etc. The whole idea rests on the illogical preposition that you would be able to travel back in time as you are now. That is essentially illogical. It places you outside the space-time continuum into a parallel universe (there it is again).

Otherwise, nice concise explanation.

Even if the analogy with quantum states is interesting, I still think that the best explanation for this paradox is the same for all paradoxes: the problem is usually in the statement. Past and future are pure abstract concepts, they are not measurable or observable. All you can physically observe is the present (or the effects of past events in the present, which is the same).
Therefore there is nowhere to "travel" to, be it the past or the future - they do not exist. You cannot travel to something that is only conceptual in nature. The same goes for infinite entities or singularities: they are mathematical abstractions that cannot be measured or observed, so in essence they do not exist as physical entities.

I always wondered, even if we could go back in time, would it actually be possible to change time?

For example, if you try to go back in time and try to kill your grandfather, no matter how many times you try, you fail. Or you go back in time to save JFK, but no matter how many times you go through it, he gets shot in the head.

Logically this doesn't seem to make sense because, why would you fail? But if time is linear, and not a product of multiple dimensions, than this would be the only thing that makes sense. The reason being this: Let's say that I go back in time to kill my grandfather because reasons. When I go, I fail because when I went to shoot him, I was tackled by a cop. Now, back to my present time. Let's say that before I decided to go back in time to kill him, my grandpa told me a story about some guy who tried to shoot him but was tackled by a cop. See where I'm going? Determinism. Time has been determined and cannot be changed, because even if someone tries to go back in time to change something, that event must have already happened back in that time.

This is totally wrong.
And it isn't about a paradox, either; it's about whether or not time exists.
Time is not time unless it is a Linear Order (that's a topological property). That is (assuming time exists), the following 3 properties hold:
1) for all x not equal to y, x precedes y or y precedes x.
2) for all x, it is not the case that x precedes x.
3) for all x, y, and z: if x precedes y and y precedes z, then x precedes z.
THEOREM: For all x, y: if x precedes y , then it is not the case that y precedes x.
PROOF: Suppose x precedes y, and by way of contradiction, that y also precedes x. Then by property 3 (transitivity), x precedes x. But by property 2, x does not precede x. Contradiction. QED.

For "time travel" (meaning going the WRONG WAY in time) to be possible, at least one of the above properties must fail. Time is not time without the linear order. Even if you accept the "branching theories" you are assuming a partial order, where properties 2 and 3 hold. Note that the proof of the above theorem only relies on properties 2 and 3.

If "time travel" is possible, then the notions of causal flow are fictional. Equivalently, determinism is a true philosophy.
If you want to go about believing in determinism, go on ahead, but otherwise you CANNOT believe in time travel.

Contradiction, because a superposition that creates a two contradictory states existing in parallel is not logical.

The way superposition works isn't that literally a particle is in multiple states at the same time, but merely that the current state of a particle can never be known until the wave is collapsed into something we can measure consistently. When a wave collapses, it takes the role of its current state and remains stable in that state.

Superposition is a mathematical solution to something that is impossible by human prediction. It's not an actual physical state of something.

Using mathematics as a literal interpretation of physical reality to make contradictions like the Grandfather Paradox not be a paradox is the wrong way to do things, and it can apply in no possible realities. The logical problem has not been defeated with this video. You cannot apply something meant to mathematically make sense of quantum mechanics to physical reality in order to make it not a contradiction. That's not why we use wave forms. We use wave forms to make the most sense possible of something that is impossible to measure with precision, and that needs to be understood when you're converting from quantum math to reality.

You can't go back to kill your grandfather. If you did, he'd already be dead. For non-time-travelers, years would count in chronological order (1916, 1917, 1918....2016). For you, the time traveler, it would count in the order you experience them (...2014, 2015, 2016, 1916, 1917, etc.). You wouldn't be able to "change" the past, because it has already happened. But you would still experience the past as a new thing and still have the feeling of free will. However, your decisions would still lead to the same events that had already happened, and we know this because they already happened. No paradox necessary.

Answer to the grandfather paradox:

If you go back in time, that doesn't mean everything that happens is undone. Rather, time is moving backwards without you. Imagine how everything works, but in reverse. The problem is that without your atoms also acting in reverse, the "past" you reach will be something completely different. Worse still, as soon as you stop "time travelling", you will find yourself unable to return to where you came from, since you already affected the timeline.

Would you kill baby Hitler?
Let's assume that by killing Adolf Hitler at age 3, we prevent the rise of the Nazis, WWII, and the Holocaust.
So, upon inventing a method to time travel to the past, we enthusiastically go to Vienna and dispose of this future mass murderer.
Now, no Hitler, no Nazi rise, no WWII, no Holocaust.
How do we justify our action to a world that only sees our action as infanticide?
Germans become terribly frustrated with the crisis of the 1920s, and can't prevent a communist takeover of Germany.
Things get so bad that frustrated German scientists research a possible rise of nationalism as an antidote to German communist tyranny, and go back in time to rescue Hitler at age three.
We would have, thus, two groups of people dissatisfied with history, going back in circles, each to prevent the other's intervention in history.
Unlike the "killing your grandfather" version, in this case we believe to be doing the right thing, even if we cannot prove that to anyone else.
Only someone living through both alternative versions of history could realize the new paradox and it's moral implications.

So I hate to rain on the parade but quantum super positioning only works on particles with little to no mass. So we're talking particles that are traveling at the speed of light. Or in the case of hydrogen molecules at the center of the Sun super positioning will work on particles with larger mass than an electron if they're under extreme pressure and heat.
When you're that hot or traveling that fast and are that small you can do all sorts of cool stuff. But the minute you have any appreciable mass the party's over............

The closest larger particles with mass get to super position is within Super Novas. Everything's great with mass until you get to Iron. Quantum superposition stops working. When you get to Iron even the intense heat and pressure can't overcome the resistance of mass to quantum mechanics. Everything freezes all quantum activity stops and Iron precipitates out of the reaction so quickly it causes the stars immense gravity to immediately collapse in on itself, creating the second largest explosion known in the Universe next to the Big Bang.

So technically you could quantum super position yourself but it would take far more energy than you have inside a super nova. It would take more energy than exists in the Universe. It's kind of a no go.......

one very simple solution to Time Travel Paradoxes that I like:

If there exists a singular flow of time, then resultant chain of events where you are born must include your attempt on your grandfathers life as a part of the past - and thus your existence is evidence of your failed attempt.

(in short, the fact that you exist to try, is proof that you already failed in the past, and therefore no paradox can occur)

This kind of paradox is popular in Hollywood. Take 'The Terminator' for example. Skynet exists because Cyberdyne Systems found the squashed Terminator of the future in a factory and could develop Skynet based on the broken chips of that Terminator. So how could Skynet send that Terminator back to the past if Skynet itself couldn't be developed without it? It's a time loop like in Henry's video; it has no beginning nor end but is a closed circle. Both events (the Terminator to the past and development of Skynet) have their effects pointed at the other's cause and that creates the paradox. Cause event 1 = effect event 2 and vice versa.

Do you also call it a "solution" if you figure out "how can I be in a faithful relationship and cheat on my most significant other w/o remorse"? - if that's the sort of "solution" we are talking about here, then, sure, the name is justified.

A solution requires a certain set of rules which to work with (a framework of rules to work within); if you reinvent the rules, you didn't solve anything, you rather broke the problem; you cheated!

So... At what point does this state collapse? It seems to me that everything in existence that this Schrödinger pair interacts with would have to either cause their indeterminate status (dead or alive, existent or non-existent) to collapse, or would have to take on an indeterminate status itself in having been interacted with or not by these indeterminate beings. If we say that this status is never going to be determined -- meaning that the dual nature is not going to 'collapse' into a sticker l single one (either dead or alive), then this means it will continue for eternity, and you might as well say that the universe has split into a multiverse as the dual-nature propagates through the ether as dual-state particles interact with others at light-speed (even photons reflecting off our dead grandfather will carry this information out at light speed).

If the state is allowed to collapse, the universe has to decide on one alternative or another (you've succeeded in killing your grandfather or not), and the paradox resumes.

So, someone please explain how I'm wrong on this -- I am not a physicist.

Everyone always overthinks time....it isn't another dimension, isn't some odd physics...thing....that you can alter or travel through, and it isn't some sort of unchangeable reality dogma. Time is a unit of measurement. Period. When you want to measure the size of an object in space you use height, depth, and width. When you want to measure it's location you use latitude and longitude or whatever works. And when you want to measure the rate it changes location when acted on by a force you use time.

You can't go back into the past because there is no past; the past is gone. It has become the present. All of the matter and energy that was the past is now the present; it is still here, changed to a new form. This includes your own body. Likewise you can't go into the future because the future doesn't exist; the matter and energy that would be the future is busy being the present. All this talk of time travel is meaningless; wasted. Time travel is just as absurd as trying to think of a way to physically travel into your own imagination. After all what we think of as "time" is nothing but memories and expectations; no more real than the dream you had last night.

Easy solution:
You went back in time to kill your grandfather,
therefore you are alive,
therefore your grandfather was alive to have children (one of which is you parent),
therefore your grandfather was not killed by you.

The effects of time travel have already been factored into our time, so you can't change the past.
(or the future for that matter, because it's the past of an even farther future)

Imagine you are a 3 dimensional object in a 2 dimensional space. For two of the three dimensions that you can move you are bound into the 2 dimensional space. But for the third you are entirely free. The laws and rules of 2 dimensional space do not apply to the 3rd dimension of traversal for the 3 dimensional object.

A person who can travel through time likely would no longer be bound by causality. You travel back in time, kill your grandfather, everything leading up to the moment before you travelled would cease to be.

However you, the now higher dimensional being, are no longer bound by causality. You, as a separate object moving along through another dimension, would be separate and untethered. All memories of you in the timeline would be altered, you would functionally not exist to other people, but you yourself would carry on.

How cause and effect would relate to you at all, at this point, is anyone's guess.

You can simulate this concept in game development platforms like Unity. Create a timeline gameobject. Then add 10 children gameobjects to that object. If you move the parent object forward all 10 children will be moved as well. They are bound to the dimensions of that parent.

Now remove one of those 10 children and place it outside of the constraints of the parent. If you move the parent now the removed child will remain its own entity. It is no longer bound by the causality of the parent.

We all live in the "local space" of our existence. To travel through time I am suggesting that you'd need to exist in the "world space", which is (I'm guessing) where our existence itself lies, with us contained within it.

This could happen by either "oh no what have I done? I must go back and fix this!" or the loop repeating until quantum fluctuations varying the specifics until you simply thought you had killed him (or died yourself, thus preventing you from attempting again).

So the superposition can collapse into 3 states:
1-you trick yourself into thinking you had succeded.
2-you fail and thought you had succeeded
3-you die in the attempt (most likely reasons being a freak accident or your grandfather killing you in self-defense)


Interestingly, all three would mean that your grandfather would likely hate the resemblance he saw in your younger self.

I've always thought that it is more likely that past events simply cannot be altered. For example, you go back in time & walk around looking for your grandfather to kill him. You finally see him on the other side of the street, you step out to cross the street, and get run down by a bus. Perhaps you suddenly remember the story your grandfather once told you about the time he was walking down the street & saw a guy get hit & killed by a bus. Or perhaps you don't... either way, events still unfolded exactly the same because absolutely nothing has changed. I think this is a much more elegant solution to the so-called Grandfather Paradox, even if it does suggest a rather philosophically deterministic universe.

Paradoxes don't and can't exist. By the very nature of their definition its impossible for a Paradox to ever exist. A paradox is a philosophical construct with no real world physical manifestation. There are no real world examples of paradoxes one can point to in order to prove their existence. The very fact that paradoxes show up in thought experiments simply proves there are things the human mind can't comprehend or doesn't yet understand. If you have a thought experiment and you come to a theoretical conclusion which has a paradox contained within it (i.e 'the grandfather paradox' theory of time travel) then your theory is wrong. It's as simple as that. You need a new theory which will remove the paradox all together

I still think there is no paradox, but the assumption of two contradicting conditions.
So, we have the time traveler, who goes back in time to kill his grandfather before the father is conceived.
Didn't we just assumed, that the grandfather was not killed in time? What I mean is the following: The fact, that the time traveler is born, means the grandfather was alive to have his way with the grandmother. So, because the time traveler was born, the grandfather was not killed in the past.
And then we assume, that somehow the person actually kills his grandfather, despite making an assumption, which automatically assumes how the killing had not happen. And here is the contradiction.
What I am saying, is that the past cannot be changed, if time traveling was possible, because the current state of the world is a result from the past. When we assume that we have a state of the world, we automatically assume the things, which resulted the state, have happened. This way we insure that we cannot assume anything that contradicts with the past.
But, what if the time traveler manages to do something? If he/she does something, that is was a part of the causes resulting the present. Or with other words - he/she would be part of the result of his/her present time.
A different way to approach this is to just scan the time line: the grandfather gets killed by something, so he never has children, so no time traveler was born, so we cannot assume, that the time traveler is the murderer, because he/she could not have been born - he/she cannot be a result from a person who died before having children.

If travelling back in time consisted of said object being transported back in timed as a dimension, while maintaining its current state, then the grandchild would kill his grandfather and realize immediately that he still exists, since there is no necessity for his matter to suddenly disappear. He would still remember the events that brought him to where he is now, but he would not have a true origin, as his previous "timeline" for lack of a better term, would have "changed" or rather it never happened... He was never born in this new timeline, but the him who was born in his previous timeline still exists in the current timeline. I see no paradox here...

Problem is, this breaks the conservation of energy. If matter and energy are interchangeable, then sending matter back in time would be essentially duplicating energy. Say sending something back in time costs 100MW of energy, then you send 200MW future battery back in time for a net value of 100MW gained... You could do this an infinite number of times, always sending the same untapped battery back in time, because you would be in a time previous to when you sent it, and therefore, it would be there and available to be sent back... This is obviously violating the laws of physics as we understand them.

However, there are plenty of theoretical ways around this break in the law of conservation of energy, and time travel isn't necessarily proven impossible yet. Don't forget, matter CAN come into existence from nothing, read into quantum mechanics for more.

This is an interesting way of looking at the paradox, but I don't know if I'd call it a solution, because it ignores, or eliminates, the timeline that would exist after the loop. In other words, it looks neat to represent the superposed timelines as a mobius strip, but that only works if time itself (not just the time traveler) is looped back on itself. That would mean that once a single person achieves time travel and changes something (creating the loop) the universe would cease to exist after that point in time. Once that happens, time would only exist within that loop, because it would become impossible to escape, so there would no longer be a timeline, for anyone or anything, after that point.

Otherwise, you're right back in the paradox, because if the timeline continues after the loop, then do you (and your grandfather) exist in it, or not? The superposition only makes sense inside the loop, but after the loop you would need to be able to resolve to a single state, and this model doesn't address that.

Of course, time travel, especially to the past, is probably impossible. That said, what I think is that going to your past and killing your grandfather wouldn't create a paradox, it would just mean "you" before you time-traveled would no longer exist (if you were to go back to your lifetime's time period). I think once a time-traveler goes to the past, that timeline is destroyed, and the timeline begins anew at the time-traveler's (past) entry point. The old timeline forward from that point just gets replaced, like taping over a VCR tape. Also, the old timeline between the traveler's (present) departure and (past) entry has no bearing on whether the traveler continues to exist (in his/her present state).
To reiterate, the traveler would keep existing, and keep all his/her memories. However, obviously, the traveler will never be born in this new timeline (and there is always only one timeline). So, the traveler could future-time-travel to a year during his/her lifetime, but the past-self will not exist (was never born). This would make his/her records, and ID invalid, and everything the traveler possessed in his/her lifetime would either not exist or belong to someone else (that is, those objects that were left behind, but anything the traveler brought along would continue to exist).
This scenario would really backfire at the traveler committing suicide via "grandfather never had my parent" concept, and would totally isolate the traveler, who would have to hide from the government. So I think it would make a cool central plot theme for a movie, just as much as the whole "disappearing because parents never had you, for some reason" scenario.

Isn't there a movie where the protagonist is in a superposed reality? You know, that one with the mailbox that sends letters back in time. He uses the mailbox to communicate with someone from the past, and by changing the past, he creates a whole set of new memories while also retaining all of his original memories. Hence his memory becomes a superposition of two different realities. Although I think that the world around him only exists as the reality that he created, and he merely remembers the unaltered version.
So my theory would be this: If you go back and change the past, you yourself become superposed, not the universe. Upon returning to the present, reality will collapse into the new timeline you created, but you will return with the memory of both timelines. Unless you were never born, in which case you wouldn't remember not existing. Effectively you become superposed with the new version of yourself, even if you no longer exist, in which case you become superposed with nothing and basically remain the same but in a timeline where you previously didn't exist.

The idea of a macroscopic superposition is a cool one, but it doesn't align with everyday experience - no matter how many boxes we open, we never see a cat that's both alive and dead at the same time. If that sort of superposed history is possible, then you need to explain why we don't experience superposed realities already.

Personally, I prefer Novikov-consistency to parallel timelines (superposed or not) - it's not that you can't go back in time to try to kill your grandfather, but that, since you exist, any attempt to kill your grandfather will fail in some way because the unlikely coincidences needed to prevent it are now more likely than any other outcome because they're the only events whose probability waves don't interfere destructively around the closed loop (like how electrons can only occupy certain orbitals around an atomic nucleus because those are the ones where the waveform interferes constructively). You can't kill your grandfather (any more than you can walk on water) but you can still use time travel to win the Lottery provided you only tell your younger self the winning numbers, not whether you win or not.

Here's a thought. How fast does time flow?

Let's assume time flows at a constant speed. Since it is constant, the speed does not matter, but sf you were to go back in time and kill your grandfather, then the change to the timeline that would normally wipe out your existence can only travel as fast as normal events and thus the effects of the death of your grandfather would never reach you, understanding that no matter where you stand in the timeline, your time moves just as fast as everyone elses time, assuming there isn't a vacuum effect that would pull you back to the present after a set period of time.

With this in mind, if you killed your grandfather and tried to return to the present, which present would you return to, your own present, or the alternate where your grandfather no longer exists? Or could you even return to the present?

The only thing you know for certain is that existence is real, because you are aware of you.
Rather than fret about what existence is (which is like asking who made god), just assign it an identity ... THE identity: the number "1".
The universe is the infinite possible relationships "1" can have with itself -- mathematics.
A subset of those possible relationships leads to metastable patterns that experience their surroundings -- consciousness.
Conscious beings are only aware of the tiny pockets of all possibility that allow them to be. And with every passing moment, having to "choose" from a vast set of possible futures is part of the requirement to stay conscious. The biggest problem with any time travel theory is the misunderstanding of what Time is.  Time is the measure of change, it is NOT an actually thing that can get manipulated.  For you to go 'back in time', you'd have to reverse the 'change' of the entire universe except for you.  (Or at least the world).  Time can be sped up or slowed by simply changing the rate of which things change, and even stopped, but it cannot be reversed.  So it comes down to like analysing the statement "I'm lying".  An obvious self paradox statement, but it's in an improper contextual framework, so it doesn't matter.

Isn't the grandfather paradox just a simplified example of the general paradox of going back in time to accomplish any task? It also works if you change it to going back in time to prevent your father from winning an award. You go back in time with the goal of preventing him from winning, but upon accomplishing that goal, your reason for time travel is gone. If your father doesn't win the award, you wouldn't go back in time to stop him from winning it, which would mean your interference preventing him would never happen, thus he would win the award, thus giving you a reason to go back in time to prevent him from winning it. Going back in time with a specific goal in mind to change something would thus remove your goal and reason to go back in time, keeping you from changing things, making it happen the way it originally happened, giving you a reason to go back in time and prevent it. Whether your goal is killing Hitler before he starts WWII, or even preventing his birth, or simply to keep yourself from failing a test, once you have accomplished that goal, your reason for having gone back in time will have never happened, preventing you from going back in time for that reason, allowing the reason to happen, sending you back in time again for that goal

Great episode, and what you said about paradoxes often not being paradoxes, how we just don't twist our thinking the right way, surprised me; I've actually thought about the same thing! An example is the old boat-new boat paradox, which I believe is actually not a paradox. If an old boat gets so many parts replaced that all the original material is gone, is it the old boat or a new boat? It's not really a paradox. The answer changes depending on who you ask; it has to do with how the strict duality of our language shapes our concept of new and old, different and same. We don't consider the in between. If we consider the in between, then it logically follows that as each new part is added, eventually, given enough time, it would be considered part of the old boat. But how quickly that part becomes old depends on the observer. One person might consider it old after a month, for another it might take ten years. The point is, the parts, and therefore the boat, is only as old or new as we think it is, and since we all think differently, there are different answers.

"Time moves in one direction" I hate this... it is so utterly wrong. No, memories are written in one direction of time, therefore we cannot perceive the bidirectionality of time. What is more accurate is the forward direction of time is the direction in which cause leads to effect. It is impossible to perceive the direction where effect leads to cause, because it would be impossible to carry memories in that direction of time. So if we did go back in time, we would just totally forget and do the exact same thing we did before like nothing happened, as long as we are in the same frame of reference as the world around us.

If we could have a bubble of time moving in the forward direction while the bubble itself was moving in the reverse direction, then that would be different.

Here's my issue with the Grandfather Paradox:
What if you go back in time - and DON'T kill your granddad?

The paradoxes just restrict what can and cannot happen in a closed time loop, i.e. no matter how hard you try you will not be able to kill your granddad.

Is it really that straightforward to suggest that a property of quantum mechanics carries over to the macroscopic world? I've read, for example, that it doesn't make literal sense to consider an entire cat to be in a superposition state, in the classic statement of the Schrodinger's cat thought experiment, because systems of many particles, like cats, decohere all but instantly. I admittedly can't claim to grasp all the subtleties of how decoherence works, as a layperson, but I might suspect that considering the entire universe to be in a superposition state is not useful for similar reasons.

Surely if I travelled back to before I was born, I'd be creating a new timeline, and my current existence would be independent of this new timeline's version of me. The very fact that I can travel to a time before I was born would mean that I don't need another version of me to exist in any other timeline I travel to. If I travelled back in time and blinded myself in the past, would current me instantly turn blind? No, because we're different physical beings. There are no physical laws to govern how changing a person or an object in the past should affect its future copy visiting that timeline, voodoo-doll-style or people-disappearing-from-photo-in-Back-to-the-Future-style. So if I travelled to the past and then to the future again, I'd better make sure that I'm going back to my own timeline (and therefore won't see the result of any changes I made to the past), or I'd better kill my past self so there aren't inexplicably two of me running around in this new future.

My biggest problem with the Grandfather paradox is the assumption that if you were to time travel there would be some invisible thread of causality connecting you to your future self. Granted, I do not know how any hypothetical method of traveling into the past would actually work and of course that's part of what makes the idea so fun to play around with in fiction. An analogy I just though of, however, is this: If we think of time as a dimension, then the past present and future are all positions along that dimension. So say I decide to leave my house for awhile on a whim. Someone's trying to kill me by blowing up my house but fortunately that happens after I went out. Would I die just because I was in my house earlier that day. No, if I'm not in the house when the explosion happens, it will not affect me that directly.
To put it simply, once I arrive in the past I exist in the past and any events or lack of events in the future cannot affect me. Even if I were to return to the future, it would simply be a "Wonderful Life" future where I'd never been born. There are of course aspects of the whole idea that the analogy doesn't quite cover but the basic idea is there.
Of course, I am also operating off of my own set of assumptions, such as time being a linear dimension similar to up and down or left and right. Also, this is just a variation of the alternate universe solution wherein our own universe is transformed into an alternate one by some grandpatrisuicidal maniac.

I always thought "time" was a word to describe the progression of chemical/physical reactions. There is no real "time", it's a metric used to track the progression of chemical/physical reactions (e.g. animal aging, planets' movements, Earth's seasons, time of day).

If you could teleport instantly to a light year away from Earth, and able to look back closely at Earth, you can "see the past" because the light that left Earth a year ago is just now hitting your eyes.

But I don't think you can time travel backward, unless you reverse chemical/physical reactions. Going through a wormhole and looking back at light from the distant pass isn't time traveling because you're not interacting with people or those things giving off that light. It would be like looking up at the sky at night, or day, and saying "hey i'm time traveling because I'm seeing the sun as it was 8 minutes ago, and the stars as they were millions of years ago". Right?

This hypothesis adds the idea of a redundancy loop within an ongoing timeline. If this happened, time would cease to continue past the time when you go back, as it would simply reset to the moment your grandfather dies, or would have. Not even a closed system would apply, as the whole world changes every time he goes back, a tiny bit at first, but progressively.

What would make more sense is a fluid timeline, where going back, and killing your grandfather actually does erase you. It would be the same as a parallel, but I find parallels to be a bit of a cheat. It's more likely that a single line's history would be rewritten, and you'd simply not have existed in the first place.

This is all assuming, of course, we'll eventually have the power to travel backwards. I don't think that will ever happen. As far as we know nothing solid will ever travel fast enough. Data, perhaps, but not a person, or an object, not unless we can somehow hitch a ride on a tachyon... I find that doubtable.
