The funny thing is, there is an "exit condition" to this causal loop. And as usual, the answer can be found in Bill Murray.

Rather than viewing the event as having two possible timelines, consider an essentially linear timeline that loops back on itself, changing slightly each time. On one of the attempts, the time traveler would eventually fail to kill his grandfather (Got the wrong guy, caught by the police, something went wrong with the time machine so never went back in time, etc etc etc) and this whole causal loop will finally break and... to an outside observer the traveler simply fails and never kills his grandfather. The whole bubble of causality can then collapse and neatly be put away. It's like Groundhog's Day, except if Bill Murray didn't remember his previous days.

But then we have to realize that we're really messing with thermodynamics... which the universe doesn't seem to like. If we send something back in time, all of a sudden we have created a great big object with a positive enthalpy. This is in apparent violation, or at least bending of the second law as entropy is temporarily decreased. The solution to this is that to send back an average sized adult human, assuming 100% efficiency, an amount of energy at least equal to e=mc^2, or something on the order of 10^19 joules of energy will have to be put in to the system. This is comparable to the amount of total energy the United States currently uses in a month. This amount of energy would have to be spent at the point in time the traveler goes back to. So in essence, a time machine wouldn't look so much like a box you go into that ends up in the past, as a gate that is opened into which someone from the future could enter. Although that energy would necessarily be reclaimed at the point in the future which the traveler first enters the time machine (Douglas Adams was right... the grammar of time travel is complicated) as much energy as 20 Tsar Bombas or so would be released.

So likely any outside observers wouldn't see the traveler going back in time to kill his grandfather... they'd see the traveler blow up in a nuclear explosion large enough to burn all flammable materials (including human flesh) within an area about the size of Ohio. The released energy would be on a similar scale to the asteroid Apophis crashing into the time traveler's lab. So, if this lab is indeed on earth, the resulting fallout would probably end civilization as we know it.

real science aside, this is my theory to why this is. Particles never have a well defined positions, speed or spin alone. that's when they can appear to be in superposition based on what you measure. now make a structure of 2 particles and you get a quantum entanglement because now one of this particle's attribute is known in relation to the other particle in the structure, thus it loses it's superposition an instead all of it's attributes are now definite with relation the other particle. now if you affect one, the other is affected as well, and you can be pretty sure in what state it was even when you measure the first particle. but still both of them only exist in one state. now if you make a structure of more then 2 particles you pretty much achieve a deadlock and all the attributes of all the particles can be definite and measured and will only be in a single state. this obviously applies to bigger structures as well.

If I could and knew how I would propose an experiment when you would be shooting one of the entangled particles through slits and I would expect them to stop acting weirdly and start acting predictably, as small marbles.

Well I have a quite simple solution.
We and everything around us travel through the time dimension at a fixed rate (well not quite fixed, but let's ignore special relativity for now). So it's safe to say that cause-and-effect travels at that same speed.
Now let's say you go back 100 years (1916) and kill your ancestor. As long as you stay in that time you will see all the effects your action has caused, because you travel forward in time at the normal speed which is the same as cause-and-effect travels has.
So if you were to never go back to 2016, events would simply life out and you would experience a chain of events that is different than you remember (one of your parents isn't in it).
If you however jump toward in time back to 2016, you have a lead on cause-and-effect, and it will never overtake you because it is running at the same speed. So your parents will be alive if you use the time-machine to go back to your starting time.

Look at time as a stream. You are drifting along. A time machine represents either swimming upstream (back in time) or downstream (forward in time). If you swim upstream, take a bottle of colouring fluid with you and open it, this event will result in a coloured trail starting at the point where you opened the bottle (=the change you made).
Swim downstream to where you started and drift again. There is no coloured trail there. The bottle will forever be behind you because it is traveling the same speed as you.

The problem with the Grandfather Paradox is that it's not a paradox.  It's an impossible situation.  The thing is, it can never start.  i.e. If you go back in time to kill your grandfather then that would mean you had done that in your past or it's not your past.   So, it's not your past, if it didn't happen in your past and you can not start it if it's not in your past.

Connie Willis's solution in her time-travel novels is that the space-time continuum simply won't allow such a paradox to occur. It is something of a running gag that her historians can never get anywhere near the Battle of Waterloo--either they end up miles away, or they arrive at a date years before or years after the battle. A lot of her plot points revolve around the need to prevent or remedy accidental discrepancies. To Say Nothing of the Dog is a light-hearted treatment of this theme, whereas Blackout/All Clear is much darker and a more serious treatment of what it means to participate in historical events that you cannot and dare not alter.

Actually there might be other solutions. Then enters most probable coherent solution wins. I.e. From point A to a possible multitude of branching futures, the most probable coherent one is the one that ends out being real. In this scenario quantum indeterminacy is the name of the game, and it will rule out any possible reality that is not coherent. I.e. if you could go back in time, you wouldn't be able to kill your grandfather, instead the world would look as if it miraculously conspired to avoid being incoherent. If you tried to shoot your grandparent with a gun, the gun would misfire, or blow in your face, thus always leading to the scenario when you were born.

This solution also provides a very interesting taught experiment in which this principle could be mad into a weapon. Let's say that country goes to war, and their scientists create a box which causes a paradox, and all you had to make sure is no matter what happens you have to guarantee with 100% certainty that the button at the top the box is pressed if you lose the war (which would in theory cause a paradox). If a country could guarantee that, it would miraculously never lose a war. If 2 with this technology that could provide the same guarantees, whit miraculously never go to war with each other.

I've actually pondered this a long time ago and came to the theory of the "unparadoxable universe".
Even if you go back in time and kill your grandfather, the event of you being born still happens and the future timeline doesn't change. You are instead rewriting the past events, because if something in the future happens certainly, it can't be changed and must happen, thus time permutes the probabilities of past superposed events to happen, changing the history.
So, from a present view, the past has happened in only one way, and you would've popped in history, and out if you travelled back to the present.
And the world goes on.

The Schrodinger grandfather

The grandfather paradox is easily resolvable. It's a paradox because some of the assumptions made have to be incompatible with others, or the accepted models of reality. People assume that if time travel is possible, one could go back in time and change things. The reason this is wrong in that for the present to be, the past must have manifested precisely, up to that point, the position of every particle in the present is dependent on the position and interaction of themselves, and others, prior. If one can send things or people to the past it would imply that their existence and interaction had manifested then, having been set in motion now. So, you could never go back and successfully kill your grandfather. You would always fail. Not because of some unseen force, but because you're living proof of what way your murder attempt went. Universes where time travel is possible are fixed timelines. So I guess all of them.

Although, I don't believe in material time travel. I'm more interested in information time travel. That is, using some form of material in the universe that due to its mechanics moves in the opposite direction of time, relative to ourselves. We would record information onto this medium, which would have allowed us to have access to that same information in the past. This would be amazing for all of human knowledge, since we could set up an inquiry process that would rely on making clear goals for what information we want to receive, like curing cancer, acquire the information and study it to identify if it satisfies our goals, after which, and upon success, we would send that information back in that same medium. This is amazing and would only output success, because if ever we were to stumble upon information in this process that does not satisfy our goals, we would simply not send it back, which would put that information's existence in question. Because such is impossible, and as long as we were rigorous in what we sent back, every finding would be exactly what was expected.
